questions.text: Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
The presence of teichoic acid and lipoteichoic acid with a thick peptidoglycan layer is a feature of gram-positive bacteria. 

  Gram positive Gram negative
Teichoic acid, lipoteichoic acid Present Absent
Thickness (Peptidoglycan) Thicker Thinner
Variety of amino acids Few Several
Aromatic and sulphur containing amino acids Absent Present
Lipopolysaccharides and outer membrane Absent Present

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient has treatment-resistant gonorrhea. Culture and sensitivity testing of his urethral discharge is planned. Which is the most preferred media?
questions.solution: Modified Thayer–Martin medium is a selective media for Neisseria species. In addition to the contents of the Thayer-Martin medium, the modified version has trimethoprim.

questions.text: The most abundant subclass of IgG present in the serum is _____.
questions.solution:
IgG1 is the most abundant subclass of IgG present in serum. It represents 65% of the total IgG.

IgG antibody has 4 subclasses. It plays a role in immunological reactions such as complement fixation, precipitation, and neutralization of viruses and toxins. IgG1 has the highest concentration in the serum, while IgG4 has the lowest concentration. 

IgG is the only maternal immunoglobulin that is normally transported across the placenta, especially the IgG1 and IgG3 subclasses. 

IgG2 is directed against polysaccharide antigens and hence is important in the host defense mechanism against encapsulated bacteria.

IgG3 is an effective activator of the complement whereas  IgG4 does not activate complement due to its compact structure.

questions.text: The transplacental transmission of the organism given in the image which causes microcephaly is:
questions.solution:
The transplacental transmission of Zika virus given in the image causes microcephaly.

The condition shown in the image is microcephaly. It is caused by Zika virus transmission from an infected pregnant mother to her child.

questions.text: Which of the following is a xenodiagnostic method?

choices.text: Rabbit ileal loop for enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli
Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a suspected dengue patient
Injecting a hamster with splenic biopsy for diagnosis of leishmaniasis
Intradermal test on guinea pigs for toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheria

questions.solution:
Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a suspected dengue patient is the xenodiagnostic method among the given options.

Xenodiagnosis (Xenos- foreign) is an indirect method of identifying the infectious disease agent or pathogen. In xenodiagnosis, the vector of a pathogenic agent is infected and the pathogen is allowed to multiply in the vector. Vectors are insects such as mosquitoes, ticks, mites, flies, fleas, and lice that transmit infections and they act as the 'foreign host.' Later, the vector is examined for the presence of the pathogen.

For example, diagnosis of Chagas disease: Laboratory bred Reduviid bugs (vector/ foreign host) are allowed to feed on the suspected patients (original host). After 4-5 weeks, the feces of the bugs are microscopically examined for amastigote forms of Trypanosoma cruzi (pathogen).

Other options:

Option A: Ligated rabbit ileal loop is used as a method of detection of Enterotoxigenic E.coli enterotoxins. It is not a method of xenodiagnosis as the vector of the pathogen is not being infected.

Option C: Injecting a hamster with splenic biopsy for diagnosis of leishmaniasis is a method of animal inoculation to help in confirmation of the diagnosis.

Option D: Intradermal test on guinea pigs for toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheria is a method of virulence testing.

questions.text: The quality of drinking water is considered to be satisfactory if the presumptive coliform count is _____.
questions.solution:
According to WHO guidelines, the quality of drinking water is considered to be satisfactory if the presumptive coliform count is 0/100 mL.

Presumptive coliform count

  • The basis of the presumptive coliform test is the inoculation of the water to be tested into tubes containing a suitable liquid medium, which are then incubated and examined after the appropriate period of time.
  • The test is called presumptive because the reaction observed in the tube may occasionally be due to the presence of some other organism or combination of organisms, and the presumption that the reaction is due to coliform organisms has to be confirmed.
  • The proportion of false-positive reactions obtained depends both on the bacterial flora of the water under examination and on the medium used.
  • Lactose broth, or MacConkey's broth, with bromocresol purple 25 as an indicator and a standardized concentration of bile salts incubated between 35°C–37°C for 48 hours, seems to be the most suitable media for presumptive tests.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used as an immediate test in the screening of urinary tract infections (UTI)?
questions.solution:
Pour plate culture (quantitative test) is not used as an immediate test for screening of UTI. However it is considered the best diagnostic test for confirmation of UTI due it’s high sensitivity and specificity.

The screening tests for UTI are as follows:

  • Wet mount examination: It is done to demonstrate pus cells in urine. 
  • Leukocyte esterase test: It is a rapid and cheaper method, and detects leukocyte esterases secreted by pus cells present in urine.
  • Nitrate reduction test (Griess test): Nitrate reducing bacteria like E. coli give a positive result.
  • Catalase test: E. coli and other bacteria that produce the enzyme catalase give a positive result.

Quantitative Culture:

  • Standardized loop technique
  • Pour plate method

questions.text: A microbiologist wants to view the cell wall of a certain bacteria. Which of the following methods cannot be used to demonstrate the cell wall?
questions.solution:
Cell wall cannot be seen with simple stains and cannot be visualized by direct light microscopy. 

It can be demonstrated by the following methods:

  • Plasmolysis
  • Microdissection
  • Reaction with specific antibodies
  • Mechanical rupture of the cell
  • Differential staining procedures (Eg Chance's method)
  • Electron microscopy

questions.text: Changes in the variable region of an immunoglobulin is _______
questions.solution:
Changes in the variable regions of heavy and light chains of an immunoglobulin is called an idiotype. 

Changes in the constant regions of the heavy chain of the immunoglobulin is isotype. 

Allotypes refer to multiple alleles that exist for some genes. This leads to subtle amino acid differences that occur in some but not all members of the same species. 

Epitope is the smallest unit of antigenicity and it is an antigenic determinant.

questions.text: Non typable H. influenza can cause all except?
questions.solution:
Non typable H. influenza will not cause meningitis, it can cause childhood otitis media, sinusitis in children and adults, puerperal sepsis and exacerbations of COPD. Typable H. influenza causes meningitis.

H. influenza is typed into 6 serotypes (a to f) based on the capsular polysaccharide.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with bumps on the skin as shown in the image below. These are pink, painless, and sometimes itchy. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Diagnosis of molluscum contagiosum is made based on the classical pink pearly wart-like lesions with a characteristic dimple at the center (umbilicated), not associated with inflammation and necrosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is a dimorphic fungi?
questions.solution:
Blastomyces dermatitidis is a dimorphic fungi.

Dimorphic fungi exist in the yeast form in body tissues and cultures maintained at 37°C, and in the filamentous form in cultures at room temperature(25°C).

Some common examples of dimorphic fungi are:

  • Blastomyces dermatitidis
  • Coccidioides immitis
  • Paracoccidioides brasiliensis
  • Talaromyces marneffei
  • Sporothrix schenckii
  • Histoplasma capsulatum
  • Coccidioides posadasii

Option A: Cryptococcus is a yeast.

Option C: Malasezzia furfur is a yeast like fungus.

Option D: Lichtheimia corymbifera is a filamentous fungi.

questions.text: Autoinfection is seen in all except _____
questions.solution:
Autoinfection is not seen in Ascaris lumbricoides.

Auto infection refers to either

  • Reinfection by organisms that are present on or within the body. It is also known as internal reinfection. E.g., Strongyloides.
  • Self-infection by direct contact with a contagious agent, as with parasite eggs in the infectious state transmitted by fingernails. E.g., Pinworm.

The following are the parasites causing autoinfection (mnemonic: CHEST.C)

  • C-Cryptosporidium parvum
  • H-Hymenolepis nana
  • E-Enterobius vermicularis
  • S-Strongyloides stercoralis
  • T-Taenia solium
  • C-Capillaria philippinensis

questions.text: Which of the following structures is involved in tonsillar herniation?
questions.solution:
Cerebellum is involved in tonsillar herniation.

Tonsillar herniation refers to the displacement of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum. This pattern of herniation is life-­threatening because it causes brainstem compression and compromises vital respiratory and cardiac centers in the medulla.

questions.text: Surrogate for endogenous insulin secretion is______.
questions.solution:
C-peptide serves as a surrogate for β-cell function.

The levels of C-peptide decreases with the loss of β-cell mass in type 1 diabetes or increases with insulin resistance-associated hyperinsulinemia. 

Insulin is produced in the β cells of the pancreatic islets as a precursor protein and is proteolytically cleaved in the Golgi complex to generate the mature hormone and a peptide byproduct, C-peptide.Both insulin and C-peptide are then stored in secretory granules and secreted in equimolar quantities after physiologic stimulation.Hence the level of C-peptide corresponds to the level of endogenous insulin.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with the blurring of vision. Urine examination showed proteinuria. Fundus examination showed dot and blot hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and cotton wool spots. Histopathology of the kidney was as shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histopathology image showing acellular periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive nodules are suggestive of Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease. It occurs in patients with diabetic nephropathy.

The following renal lesions are encountered in diabetic nephropathy:

  • Glomerular lesions -
    • Capillary basement membrane thickening
    • Diffuse mesangial sclerosis
    • Nodular glomerulosclerosis/ Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease
    • Intercapillary glomerulosclerosis
  • Renal vascular lesions - hyaline arteriolosclerosis
  • Pyelonephritis - necrotizing papillitis

Option A: In amyloidosis, glomerular deposits appear as thickenings of the mesangial matrix, forming interlacing broad ribbons of amyloid.

Option B: In focal segmental glomerulosclerosis, there is focal and segmental hyalinosis and sclerosis of the capillary wall with lipid droplets in the sclerosed area.

Option D: In lupus nephritis, immune complex deposits are seen in the mesangium or along the entire basement membrane (wire loop lesions), with mesangial cell proliferation.

questions.text: Which of the following organs do not show hemosiderin deposits in hemochromatosis?
questions.solution:
Testes do not show any hemosiderin deposits in hemochromatosis.

Hypogonadism in hemochromatosis is not due to deposition of iron in the testis, but due to a derangement in the hypothalamic–pituitary axis, resulting in decreased gonadotrophins and testosterone levels. The testis will appear small and atrophic.

Deposition of hemosiderin is seen in the following organs (in decreasing order of severity): liver, pancreas, myocardium, pituitary gland, adrenal gland, thyroid and parathyroid glands, joints, and skin.

questions.text: What is the most common mechanism behind sudden cardiac death?
questions.solution:
The mechanism behind sudden cardiac death (SCD) is most often a lethal arrhythmia, e.g., asystole or ventricular fibrillation.

Coronary artery disease is the leading cause of SCD, responsible for 80% to 90% of cases. But, the mechanism of SCD is most often a lethal arrhythmia. Infarction need not occur. Most of the patients who have SCD but are successfully resuscitated do not show any enzymatic or ECG evidence of myocardial necrosis.

Ischemic injury can directly affect the major components of the conduction system. But, most cases of fatal arrhythmia are triggered by electrical irritability of the myocardium.

questions.text: What is the maximum duration for TRALI to occur after blood transfusion?
questions.solution:
The maximum duration for TRALI to occur after blood transfusion is 6 hours.

TRALI: Transfusion-related acute lung injury

It results from the transfusion of donor plasma that contains high-titer anti-HLA class II antibodies that bind recipient leukocytes. The leukocytes aggregate in the pulmonary vasculature and release mediators that increase capillary permeability.

The implicated donors are frequently multiparous women.

The recipient develops symptoms of hypoxia (and signs of noncardiogenic pulmonary edema, including bilateral interstitial infiltrates visible on chest x-ray image.

Treatment is supportive, and patients usually recover without sequelae.

questions.text: All of the following conditions are related to the same pathology except
questions.solution:
Alzheimer's disease, unlike the rest, is not an alpha-synucleinopathy. It is a β-amyloidopathy characterized by the accumulation of Aβ amyloid protein.

Alpha-synucleinopathies: These are a group of neurodegenerative disorders, that are characterized by aggregation of α-Synuclein in neurons, nerve fibers, or glial cells to form inclusion bodies.

questions.text: The most common site of carcinoma in the breast is ____.
questions.solution:
Upper outer quadrant is the most common site of carcinoma in the breast.

Approximately 50% of carcinomas are located in the upper outer quadrant, 10% in each of the remaining quadrants, and about 20% in the central or subareolar region.

A palpable mass is the most common clinical sign of invasive breast carcinoma.

Triple assessment is recommended for the diagnosis of any palpable breast lump that includes- Clinical examination, radiological assessment (mammography/USG) and pathological assessment (FNAC/biopsy)

Techniques of palpation of breast (asked in AIIMS Nov 2018)

  1. Vertical strip/lines pattern
  2. Circular pattern
  3. Wedges or radial spokes pattern

questions.text: Histopathological examination of lesions in sarcoidosis shows all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Histopathological examination of lesions in sarcoidosis does not show Birbeck bodies. These bodies are seen in Langerhan cell histiocytosis.

The cardinal histopathologic feature of sarcoidosis, irrespective of the organ involved, is the non-caseating granuloma. Two other microscopic features are sometimes seen in the granulomas: 

  • Schaumann bodies: Inclusion bodies with concentric rings of calcification
  • Asteroid bodies: Stellate inclusions in the giant cells
  • Birefringent crystalline particles composed of calcium

Noncaseating granulomas can also be seen in:

  • Berylliosis
  • Crohn's disease
  • Foreign body granuloma

questions.text: Following appearance in barium study is seen in:
questions.solution:
X-ray shows lead pipe appearance of colon. It is the classical barium enema finding in chronic ulcerative colitis. There is complete loss of haustral markings in the diseased section of colon, and the organ appears smooth walled and cylindrical.

Ulcerative colitis: Diffuse involvement of mucosa and submucosa of colon.

Early changes in ulcerative colitis:

  • Mucosal granularity
  • Fine granular pattern
  • Mucosal stippling
  • Collar button ulcers
  • Deep collar stud ulcers
  • Coarse granular pattern

questions.text: McCallum’s patch is seen mostly in the _____.
questions.solution:
In rheumatic heart disease, subendocardial lesions may induce irregular thickenings called McCallum plaques, usually in the left atrium.

Image- Thickened endocardium or McCallum's patch in a heart affected by rheumatic heart disease.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presented with scrotal swelling and ataxia. Which among the following could likely be a cause?
questions.solution:
The most likely cause in the following case is Non-Hodgkin lymphoma(NHL). Diffuse large B cell lymphoma (DLBCL), a type of NHL is the most common lymphoma. NHL affects the elderly age group and extranodal presentation is common. DLBCL can involve CNS, and CNS involvement is particularly common in the testicular, paranasal sinus, or bone marrow involvement.

Primary testicular lymphoma is common in NHL compared to Hodgkin lymphoma. Primary testicular lymphoma(PTL) is an aggressive and uncommon form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma(NHL) usually affecting the elderly age group(>60y). It typically presents as a painless, firm testicular mass. Constitutional symptoms are uncommon, and if present warrant a systemic involvement. Metastasis involves the central nervous system (CNS), skin, contralateral testis, and pleura resulting in local complications.

Even though ataxia is seen as a paraneoplastic symptom due to cerebellar degeneration in Hodgkin lymphoma, testicular involvement is very rare and so far only 5 cases have been reported. Hodgkin lymphoma arises in a single node or chain of nodes and spreads first to anatomically contiguous lymphoid tissues. The extranodal presentation is rare. The extranodal disease can occur at any site like lung, liver, bone, and bone marrow is most common if it occurs. The central nervous system and the testis are exceptionally rare sites for Hodgkin's lymphoma. Thus Hodgkin's lymphoma can be ruled out.

Other options:

A) Glioblastoma multiforme is a highly malignant tumor, common in older adults in the fifth and sixth decades. The most common locations are the frontal and temporal lobes. The tumor may spread and invade the other hemisphere, resulting in a characteristic butterfly appearance. Extracranial metastases of malignant gliomas are extremely rare due to:

  • Absence of a lymphatic system in the brain and spinal cord for systemic dissemination
  • Dense dura around intracranial veins, preventing the penetration of the tumor
  • Lack of nurturing stroma in other organs prevents the proliferation of glioblastoma cells

Therefore the tumor metastasizing to the testis is very much unlikely and glioblastoma can be ruled out.

Image showing MRI(magnetic resonance imaging) of glioblastoma

Option D) Testicular cancer is the most common cancer in men aged from 15 to 35 years. Germ cell tumors(GCT) account for 90%–95% of cases.  Non-seminomatous form (NSGCT) metastasizes to the lungs, liver, central nervous system, and bone in order of frequency. The frequency of brain metastases is very low, not exceeding 1.2%. 

Note: This is a controversial question. A more detailed clinical history and examination than what is provided in the stem are required for us to arrive at a definitive diagnosis.

questions.text: The diagnostic standard for amyloidosis is __________.
questions.solution:
The diagnostic standard for amyloidosis is staining of abdominal fat aspirate.

Diagnosis of amyloidosis

  • Congo red staining of aspirated abdominal fat is the investigation of choice.
  • The histological examination of the biopsy material is the commonest confirmatory method.
  • The sites for the biopsy depend on the organ involved in systemic amyloidosis.

questions.text: Calnexin is mainly involved in:

choices.text: Signaling release of calcium from endoplasmic reticulum

questions.solution:
Calnexin is a lectin chaperone that is involved in the folding of glycoproteins and it is located in the membrane of the endoplasmic reticulum.

It binds to various proteins like the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) antigens and plasma proteins. It makes the proteins stay within the endoplasmic reticulum until they are properly folded.

Calreticulin is another chaperone and calcium-binding protein, similar to calnexin but it is not membrane-bound.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids is not formed after post-translational modification?
questions.solution:
Selenocysteine, the 21st amino acid, is formed by co-translational modification. It is coded by the UGA codon, which is normally a stop codon. The protein synthetic apparatus can identify a selenocysteine-encoding UGA by the presence of the selenocysteine insertion sequence (SECIS) in the untranslated region of mRNA.

Selenocysteine is present at the active site of several human enzymes that catalyze redox reactions such as thioredoxin reductase, glutathione peroxidase, and deiodinase.

Impairment in human selenoproteins have been implicated in tumorigenesis and atherosclerosis and are associated with selenium deficiency cardiomyopathy (Keshan disease).

questions.text: Which of the following retinoids has major role to play in vision?
questions.solution:
Retinal (retinaldehyde) has a major role to play in vision.

In the retina, retinaldehyde functions as the prosthetic group of the light-sensitive opsin proteins, which form rhodopsin (in rods) and iodopsin (in cones). Rhodopsin contains 11-cis retinal bound to opsin.

The absorption of light by rhodopsin causes series of photoisomerization resulting in the formation of metarhodopsin II, which initiates a nerve impulse, finally, metarhodopsin II hydrolysis to release all-trans-retinaldehyde and opsin.

All-trans-retinaldehyde is isomerized to 11-cis-retinal which combines with opsin to regenerate rhodopsin, this visual cycle is known as Wald's visual cycle.

Note: Retinoic acid is similar to steroid hormone and binds to the nuclear receptor and helps in regulating gene expression.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about fat-soluble vitamins is true?

choices.text: Vitamin C is a fat soluble vitamin
Stored in the liver and the adipose tissue

questions.solution:
Fat-soluble vitamins are stored in the liver and adipose tissue.

Vitamins can be broadly classified into two categories:

  • Fat-soluble vitamins: Vitamins A, D, E, K
  • Water-soluble vitamins:  Vitamin B complex and Vitamin C

Few properties of fat-soluble vitamins:

  • Hydrophobic in nature
  • Transported in blood by the lipoproteins, such as chylomicrons
  • Stored in the liver and the adipose tissue 

Conditions affecting the digestion and absorption of the lipid-soluble vitamins causing deficiency of these vitamins include: a very low-fat diet, steatorrhea, and disorders of the biliary system.

questions.text: DNA expansion with repeats of CTG triplet sequence leads to which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Myotonic dystrophy is an autosomal dominant disease caused due to triplet repeat expansion of DNA in the DMPK gene. The polynucleotide sequence involved in the expansion is the CTG sequence. This leads to an abnormal expression of myotonin protein kinase..
In the childhood form of DM,intellectual disability and behavioural problems are often the predominant features. Other key findings of classic DM include:

 

  • Myotonia or delay in muscle relaxation.
  • Weakness and atrophy of facial and distal limb musculature.
  • Cardiac abnormalities including cardiomyopathy and conduction disturbances
  • Frontal hair loss, cataracts, insulin resistance.

 


Other options:

Option B- Fragile X syndrome is caused due to trinucleotide repeats- CGG- in the FMR1 gene of the X chromosome.

Option C- Huntington’s disease is an autosomal dominant disease caused due to triplet expansion of DNA by the CAG sequence. Clinical features include dementia,loss of motor control and affective disorder.

Option D-Spinocerebellar ataxia is caused by triplet expansion of DNA by the CAG sequence. Clinical features include progressive ataxia and dysarthria.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male patient presents with recent onset of photosensitivity and development of vesicles and bullae on the sun-exposed areas of his skin as shown below. A urine analysis showed the presence of elevated levels of uroporphyrin I and normal red cell uroporphyrin. Identify the false statement regarding the patient's illness.

UROD- Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase

choices.text: Low dose hydroxychloroquine is used in management
Associated with increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma

questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is porphyria cutanea tarda. The false statement regarding the patient's illness is that the hepatic iron stores are normal. The hepatic iron stores are increased.

Porphyrias are a group of metabolic disorders caused by the deficiency/ abnormal functioning of enzymes involved in heme biosynthesis which leads to subsequent accumulation and excretion of porphyrins/their precursors.

Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT) is a type of hepatic, cutaneous porphyria caused due to a deficiency in the enzyme uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase, which converts uroporphyrinogen III to coproporphyrinogen III. Mutations of the uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase (UROD) gene are present.

The accumulated porphyrins transported to the skin act as photosensitizers. Hence, the patients usually present with skin fragility and bullae on sun-exposed skin, in areas of repeated trauma such as the dorsal aspect of the hands, the forearms, face, and ears. The erosions produced by the rupture of skin lesions heal with purplish discoloration. Hypertrichosis, mottled pigmentary change, and scleroderma-like induration are associated features.

Diagnosis is made by the classical clinical feature of photosensitivity with elevated urine, stool, and plasma uroporphyrin with normal red cell uroporphyrin. 

PCT is the most readily treated form of porphyria. Management includes:

  • Phlebotomies to deplete iron, guided by serum ferritin level estimation.
  • Hydroxychloroquine to remove excess porphyrins from the liver. A low-dose hydroxychloroquine regimen is preferred to avoid hepatotoxicity.

 

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria
  • Erythropoietic porphyria

Hepatic porphyria is caused due to enzyme deficiency early in the pathway of heme synthesis. There is an accumulation of ALA and PBG. The patient principally presents with neurovisceral symptoms.

Erythropoietic porphyria is caused due to enzyme deficiency late in the pathway of heme synthesis. There is an accumulation of porphyrins which leads to cutaneous photosensitivity.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man suffering from diabetes mellitus for 10 years came for a routine checkup. His lipid profile revealed increased TG (triacylglycerol) and VLDL (very low-density lipoprotein). What is the cause of this abnormal lipid profile?

choices.text: Increased activity of lipoprotein lipase and decreased activity of hormone sensitive lipase
Increased activity of hormone sensitive lipase and decreased lipoprotein lipase activity
Increase in peripheral function of LDL receptors
Increased in activity of hepatic lipase

questions.solution:
In chronic diabetes, the value of TG and VLDL are increased due to an increase in hormone-sensitive lipase and a decrease in lipoprotein lipase.

Insulin has an inhibitory effect on hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL). In diabetes, low insulin corresponds to an increase in HSL activity. This promotes the breakdown of lipids and a release of TG and free fatty acids from the adipose tissue.

Insulin induces the activity of lipoprotein lipase (LPL) which is present on the capillary walls. LPL promotes hydrolysis of TG and the degradation of the transport proteins, VLDL and chylomicrons. In diabetes, low insulin leads to decreased LPL activity which corresponds to an increase in VLDL and TG.

Related Pearl: Hormone sensitive lipase Vs lipoprotein lipase

   HSL  Lipoprotein lipase
Location  Adipocyte  Capillaries
Action  Hydrolyse TAG in adipose   tissue  Hydrolyse TAG in chylomicron , VLDL
Acts in the state of  Fasting (Glucagon)  Fed (Insulin)

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with muscle weakness, vomiting, and seizures accompanied by focal neurological deficits. Her developmental milestones were normal during the previous visits. Laboratory tests show lactic acidosis and microscopic findings of muscle biopsy are shown below.  What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario shows a child who had normal development previously and then presenting with symptoms of lactic acidosis and stroke(seizures with focal neurological deficits), suggestive of MELAS [mitochondrial encephalopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke] .

The microscopy of muscle biopsy with modified Gomori trichrome staining shows ragged red fibers (arrowhead). Based on these features, the child is probably suffering from MELAS, which is a mitochondrial inherited condition due to complex I or complex IV deficiency.

questions.text: In the metabolism of vitamin D, where does the conversion of calcidiol to calcitriol occur?
questions.solution:
In the metabolism of vitamin D, the conversion of calcidiol (25-hydroxycholecalciferol) to calcitriol (1,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol) occurs in the kidney.

Vitamin D metabolism occurs in 3 steps:

Step 1- Skin: 7-dehydrocholesterol (an intermediate in cholesterol synthesis that accumulates in the skin) undergoes a nonenzymic reaction on exposure to ultraviolet light, yielding cholecalciferol, which is absorbed into the bloodstream. Note that 7-Dehydrocholesterol and cholecalciferol already contain one hydroxy group.

Step 2- Liver:  Cholecalciferol is hydroxylated to 25-hydroxycholecalciferol. This is released into the circulation bound to a vitamin D–binding globulin, which is the main storage form of the vitamin.

Step 3- Kidney: 25-hydroxycholecalciferol is converted to 1,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol, the biologically active form by the enzyme 1α-hydroxylase.

questions.text: The correct order of steps in Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) is:
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of events for PCR among the given options is Denaturation, Annealing, Extension.

The process of PCR is as below:

The DNA sample is first heat-denatured at >90°C ( 90-96 degrees Celsius for 3 minutes) to separate the two strands of the template DNA containing the target sequence; the primers ( which attach to the 3' end of the flanking sequence) are added in excess, are allowed to anneal to the DNA (typically at 50-75°C) in order to generate the required template-primer hybridization complex. Under suitable conditions and presence of deoxynucleotides, elongation of the DNA stand occurs. 

Below is an image showing the various ingredients for carrying out PCR.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presented with jaundice and tiredness. On investigation his AST was 150 IU/L, ALT was 175 IU/L and bilirubin was 4.5mg/dl. Serum ceruloplasmin levels were found to be low. Which of the following minerals is used in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Wilson’s disease. Zinc is used in the treatment of this condition.

Wilson’s disease is an autosomal recessive condition, due to the mutation of the ATP 7B gene, which leads to a faulty mechanism of copper transportation. 

There is failure of excretion of copper from the liver, which then accumulates in the liver, spills over into the blood and deposits in sites such as brain and cornea. This can lead to liver disease, hemolysis, a movement disorder neurologic disease and/or psychiatric illness.

Zinc acts by blocking the intestinal absorption of copper, thus decreasing the amount of copper in the body.

questions.text: Array CGH can detect all except?
questions.solution:
Array CGH cannot detect balanced translocation.

Array based Comparative Genomic Hybridization:

In Array CGH, two genomes are compared. The test DNA and the reference DNA are labelled with two different flourescent dyes (red and green respectively) and are added to a DNA chip spotted with entire human genome.

  • If the contribution of both sample are equal for a given chromosomal region, then all spots on the array will flouresce yellow.
  • If test sample has amplification, that spot will floresce red
  • If test sample has deletion, that spot will flouresce green

Uses of Array CGH:

  • To detect gene amplification
  • To detect gene deletion 
  • To detect copy number variations

questions.text: Methyl-tetrahydro-folic acid gets accumulated in deficiency of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Accumulation of methyl tetrahydro folic acid is seen in vitamin B12 deficiency. Vitamin B12 acts as a cofactor of methionine synthase, an enzyme involved in the regeneration of tetrahydrofolate from methyl-tetrahydrofolate. Hence, in vitamin B12 deficiency methyl-tetrahydrofolate accumulates leading to functional folate deficiency known as the folate trap.

 

The conversion of 5,10-methylene-THF into 5-methyl-THF (methyltetrahydrofolate) is an irreversible process. The major source of tetrahydrofolate for tissues is 5-methyl-THF. The only way to make further use of 5-methyl-THF and to maintain the folate cycle is by the vitamin B12-dependent remethylation of homocysteine to methionine by the methionine synthase enzyme.

Decreased activity of methionine synthase in vitamin B12 deficiency results in the accumulation of methyltetrahydrofolate, which cannot be used, resulting in a folate trap. The folate cycle acts as the link between the functions of folate and vitamin B12, and deficiency of vitamin B12 can cause a functional deficiency of folate.

Note: Since vitamin B12 is also linked to the regeneration of methionine from homocysteine, its deficiency can result in hyperhomocysteinemia as well. This in turn increases the risk of atherosclerosis, hypertension, and thrombosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a suicidal enzyme?
questions.solution:
Cyclooxygenase is a suicidal enzyme.

A suicidal enzyme is one which undergoes self-destruction in order to terminate its own activity. In this case it switches off the prostaglandin activity.

Suicide inhibitors are specialized substrate analogs. They contain a chemical group that can be transformed by the target enzyme.

After binding to the active site, catalysis by the enzyme generates a highly reactive group that forms a covalent bond and blocks the function of the enzyme.

Related Pearl: Some Examples of Suicidal Inhibitors

Suicidal Inhibitors

Enzyme

Allopurinol

Xanthine oxidase

Aspirin

Cyclooxygenase

5-Flurouracil

Thymidylate synthase

Penicillin

Transpeptidase

DFMO

Ornithine Decarboxylase

questions.text: A 5-year-old female child with polyneuropathy, sensorineural deafness, and cerebellar ataxia has the following finding on fundus examination. Lab reveals increased blood levels of phytanic acid. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows fundoscopy findings of retinitis pigmentosa. This along with the given clinical scenario is suggestive of Refsum’s disease. It is a neurologic disorder that results from the defect in alpha oxidation of fatty acids such as phytanic acid in the peroxisome leading to elevated levels of phytanic acid in the blood. 

 

Option B- Usher syndrome is characterized by sensorineural deafness and retinitis pigmentosa (but symptoms are not affected by restricting phytanic acid)

Option C- Zellweger Syndrome is also known as cerebrohepatorenal syndrome. It is caused by mutations in the PEX family of genes also called peroxins involved in peroxisome biogenesis /peroxisomal enzymes themselves. Biochemical findings include accumulation of very-long-chain fatty acids, abnormalities of the synthesis of bile acids, marked reduction of plasmalogens. 

Option D- Adrenoleukodystrophy is an X-linked recessive disorder of β-oxidation of fatty acids. There is a very large chain fatty acids buildup in the adrenal glands, the white matter of the brain, and testes. It is a progressive disease that can lead to adrenal gland crisis, coma, and death.

questions.text: Which of the following is a protein separation technique based on molecular/ ionic charge?
questions.solution:
Ion exchange chromatography is a protein separation technique based on molecular/ ionic charge.

Other techniques based on molecular charge:

  • Agarose gel electrophoresis
  • Cellulose acetate electrophoresis
  • Isoelectric focusing
  • High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC)

Related Pearl: Types of Chromatography

Chromatography types Property used for separation
Paper chromatography Based on polarity, Least polar moves faster
Thin layer chromatography Based on polarity, Least polar moves faster
Ion exchange chromatography Based on charge – charge interaction
Size exclusion chromatography Based on descending order of Stokes radius which is a function of molecular mass and shape
Affinity chromatography Based on specific ligand binding behaviour
Hydrophobic interaction chromatography Based on hydrophobic interaction

questions.text: Von Gierke’s disease is due to the deficiency of ______
questions.solution:
Von Gierke’s disease occurs due to deficiency of enzyme Glucose 6 phosphatase.

Glycogen storage disease type I (GSD I), or von Gierke disease, is the most common of the glycogen storage diseases. 

Clinical manifestations result, directly or indirectly, from:

  • Inability to maintain an adequate blood glucose level during the post-absorptive hours of each day
  • Organ changes due to glycogen accumulation
  • Excessive lactic acid generation
  • Damage to tissue from hyperuricemia
  • In GSD bleeding and infection risk from blood cell effects

questions.text: Which of the following drugs should be sold only on prescription from a registered medical practitioner?
questions.solution:
Schedule H drugs should be sold only if the prescription is from a registered medical practitioner (RMP). 

Important schedules under “drugs and cosmetics act” are

  • C and C1: Biological and special products
  • F and F1: Bacterial vaccines
  • G: Drugs that must be labeled with the word “caution” should not be taken without medical supervision
  • J: List of disease and ailments which a drug may not claim to prevent or cure
  • M: Good Manufacturing Practices (GMP)
  • P: Expiry period of drug formulations
  • W: Drugs marketed under generic name only
  • X: Psychotropic drugs requiring a special license for manufacture and sale
  • Y: Requirements and guidelines on clinical trials, import, and manufacture of new drugs

Related Pearl: Drug regulatory schedules 1940: (2016 update)

Schedule D List of drugs exempted from the provision of import of drugs.

Blood and blood products

F I - Production of Bacterial vaccines, Anti- Sera

F II - Specification of standards for Surgical dressing

FF- Specification of standard Ophthalmic preparation
Schedule G With a label of Caution, dangerous to use except under medical supervision.
Schedule H Prescription drugs.
Schedule J List of diseases that a drug may not prevent or cure. Eg - HIV & Atherosclerosis
Schedule M Regulations regarding good manufacturing practices

Schedule X Drugs having abuse and dependence liability.

questions.text: The drug of choice in anaphylactic shock is?

choices.text: Adenosine 6 mg followed by 12 mg IV

questions.solution:
The drug of choice in anaphylactic shock is adrenaline 0.3 - 0.5 mL of 1:1000 IM (1mg/mL). 

IM injection is preferred over intravenous (IV) bolus because it is faster in many situations and safer (ie, lower risk of cardiovascular complications, such as severe hypertension and ventricular arrhythmias). There is a much greater risk of causing harmful side effects by inappropriate dosage or misdiagnosis of anaphylaxis when using IV adrenaline.

Intravenous (IV) route can also be used 0.5 to 1 mL of 1:10,000 (0.1mg/ml).

questions.text: Nitrates act by which of the following second messengers?
questions.solution: Nitrates act by increasing the concentration of second messenger cGMP.

questions.text: Which of the following is a naturally occurring opioid?
questions.solution:
Morphine is a naturally occurring opioid.

Options A and C: pentazocine and fentanyl are synthetic opioids.

Option B: heroin is semisynthetic opioid.

Related Pearl: Classification of Opioids

Naturally Occurring:

  • Morphine
  • Codeine (methyl morphine)
  • Papaverine
  • Thebaine

Semisynthetic:

  • Heroin (diacetyl morphine)
  • Dihydromorphone, morphinone
  • Thebaine derivatives (e.g., etorphine, buprenorphine)

Synthetic:

  • Morphinan series (e.g., levorphanol, butorphanol)
  • Diphenylpropylamine series (e.g., methadone)
  • Benzomorphan series (e.g., pentazocine)
  • Phenylpiperidine series (e.g., meperidine, fentanyl, sufentanil, alfentanil, remifentanil)

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to be useful in a patient with severe COVID-19?
questions.solution: Favipiravir was not approved for severe COVID-19, it inhibits viral RNA polymerase and was the first oral drug approved in India for restricted emergency use for the treatment of mild to moderate COVID-19 patients.

questions.text: The mainstay of treatment of isoniazid overdose is _______
questions.solution:
The mainstay of treatment of isoniazid overdose is intravenous pyridoxine.

Prolonged treatment with isoniazid leads to the deficiency of pyridoxine which leads to peripheral neuritis and other neurological manifestations like paresthesias, numbness, and other CNS effects.

Isoniazid overdose results in inhibition of pyridoxine availability to neurons and decreases the levels of GABA, which in turn lowers the seizure threshold.

Benzodiazepines are preferred to treat seizures in isoniazid overdose.

questions.text: The antimicrobial treatment initiated in a patient who is not yet infected is called as____________.
questions.solution:
The antimicrobial treatment initiated in a patient who is not yet infected is called as prophylactic therapy. The goal is to prevent infection in some patients and to prevent dangerous manifestations of infections in other patients. 

Preemptive therapy: Therapy in an asymptomatic individual with evidence of infection (high-risk).

Empirical therapy: Broad therapy in a patient with symptoms of infection but no microbiological confirmation of the causative agent. 

Definitive therapy: Definite therapy directed against microbiologically confirmed microbes with sensitive agents.

questions.text: Metformin is considered as a first line agent for the management of
questions.solution:
Metformin is considered as first line agent along with lifestyle modifications in the management of type 2 diabetes mellitus. 

Option A: Metformin is not considered as first line agent for all PCOS (Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome) patients for fertility induction as clomiphene has shown better outcomes. Metformin can be preferred in patients with glucose intolerance. 

Option B: Metformin is not indicated in type 1 diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child developed fever during the epidemic of influenza. Which of the following drug is contraindicated in this child?
questions.solution:
Aspirin is contraindicated in this child due to the risk of development of Reye syndrome. Aspirin and other salicylates are contraindicated in children and young adults less than 20 years of age with viral fever because they have a risk of developing Reye's syndrome.

Features of Reye syndrome include:

  • Acute onset of encephalopathy
  • Liver dysfunction
  • Fatty infiltration of the liver

questions.text: Which of the following is considered as a dietary supplement in many countries?
questions.solution:
• Methylcobalamin is the active coenzyme form of vitamin B12 required for the synthesis of methionine and S-adenosylmethionine that is required for the synthesis of myelin. It is considered as a dietary supplement in many countries.
  • Methylcobalamin is promoted for correcting neurological deficits in diabetic, alcoholic and other forms of neuropathies.

questions.text: Which of the following is indicated in the management of Pulmonary Artery Hypertension?
questions.solution:
Selective PDE 5 inhibitors are indicated in the management of pulmonary artery hypertension (PAH).

Inhibition of PDE 5 in the pulmonary bed leads to a reduction in the hydrolysis of cGMP which causes pulmonary vasodilation.

Sildenafil and Tadalafil are the PDE-5 inhibitors approved for use in PAH.

questions.text: A young male developed 5 episodes of loose stools 2 hours after eating in a restaurant. He is afebrile and has mild dehydration. What should be the treatment?
questions.solution:
It is a case of acute diarrhea in an afebrile, stable patient which can be managed with ORS alone.

Management of diarrhea:

  • Mild-moderate dehydration - ORS.
  • Severe dehydration- IV fluids are given.
  • Afebrile patient - No antibiotics are not given.
  • Febrile patient - empirical antibiotics. If only bacterial etiology is suspected, ciprofloxacin is given. If giardiasis is suspected, metronidazole or tinidazole are recommended.

questions.text: The monoclonal antibody approved for use in HIV-1 is:
questions.solution:
Ibalizumab is a monoclonal antibody approved for use in the treatment of resistant HIV-1 infections. 

Ibalizumab blocks HIV-1 from infecting CD4+ T cells by binding to domain 2 of CD4 cells. It also interferes with post-attachment steps required for the entry of HIV-1 virus particles into host cells.

Option A -Ixekizumab is an IL-17A antagonist indicated in moderate to severe plaque psoriasis. 

Option C- Idarucizumab is a reversal agent for dabigatran.

Option D- Ipilimumab is a monoclonal antibody against CTLA-4 and acts as an immune checkpoint inhibitor.

questions.text: How many spinal nerves are present in the cervical region?
questions.solution:
There are 8 pairs of spinal nerves in the cervical region.

The cerebrospinal nervous system includes 12 pairs of cranial nerves and 31 pairs of spinal nerves.

The 31 pairs of spinal nerves are distributed as follows:

  • Cervical nerves - 8 pairs
  • Thoracic nerves-12 pairs
  • Lumbar nerves-5 pairs
  • Sacral nerves-5 pairs
  • Coccygeal nerves-1 pair

questions.text: Fenestrated capillaries are absent in_________
questions.solution:
Fenestrated capillaries are absent in the lungs.

Fenestrated capillaries have gaps between endothelial cells. They are present in certain tissues that allow the passage of larger molecules such as the renal glomeruli, endocrine glands, intestinal mucosa, and pancreas.

The following image shows illustrations of different types of capillaries:

questions.text: The organ of Rosenmuller is a remnant of the_______.
questions.solution:
The organ of Rosenmuller, also known as epoophoron, is a remnant of the mesonephric tubule in females.

The mesonephric tubules gives rise to the following structures and remnants:

  • Females: epoophoron and paroophoron
  • Males: efferent ductules (ductuli efferentes or vasa efferentia), lobules of the head of the epididymis, and paradidymis.

questions.text: The below image shows the histology of the hair follicle. Identify the structure marked in the image:
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the above image is the outer root sheath.

The hair is made up of following layers (from within outwards):

  • Medulla- consisting of vacuolated and moderately keratinised cells.
  • Cortex- Consisting of densely packed and heavily keratinised cells.
  • Inner root sheath- This includes cuticle, inner Huxley's layer and outer Henle's layer.
  • Outer root sheath- These appear as clear cells as they contain glycogen.
  • Glassy membrane
  • Connective tissue sheath

The below image shows the histological image of the hair with its different layers.

questions.text: Multiple layers of intertwining anucleate keratinocytes are seen in _________
questions.solution:
Multiple layers of intertwining anucleate keratinocytes are seen in stratum corneum.

The deepest layer, stratum basale, contains the stem cells which divide and start moving superficially. As cells move more superficially, they begin to lose their nuclei and become progressively dehydrated and flattened. Traces of flattened nuclei may be seen in some cells of stratum lucidum.

Stratum corneum (horny layer) consists of multiple layers of anucleate keratinocytes that often intertwine resulting in a basketweave appearance.

Stratum corneum, because of its thickness,  prevents entry of microbes from the environment into the body as well as preventing leakage of fluids from the body to the environment, called barrier function.

questions.text: The newly discovered salivary glands are predominantly present over

choices.text: Posterior ⅔ rd of the tongue

questions.solution:
The newly discovered salivary glands are predominantly present over torus tubarius. Torus tubarius is the anatomical structure formed by the cartilage that supports the entrance of the auditory tube.

The proposed name of these newly identified glands is tubarial salivary glands. These glands extend caudally to the pharyngeal wall and cranially to Rosenmuller's fossa.

Positron emission tomography/computed tomography with radio-labeled ligands to the prostate-specific membrane antigen (PSMA PET/CT) can visualize these salivary glands with high sensitivity and specificity.

Clinical significance:

It has been reported that radiotherapy over the location of these glands has led to xerostomia and dysphagia. Sparing these glands, thus, might improve the quality of life of patients receiving radiotherapy.

questions.text: Identify the cranial nerve passing through the red point in the image
questions.solution:
In the given image, the dorsal aspect of the brainstem is marked and the cranial nerve that is passing there is the trochlear nerve (CN IV). 

The trochlear nerve is the fourth cranial nerve that originates from the trochlear nuclei within the midbrain at the level of the inferior colliculus. It is the only cranial nerve that emerges from the dorsal surface of the brainstem and has the longest intracranial course. It passes on to the lateral surface of the crus of cerebellar peduncle and lateral wall of the cavernous sinus. The nerve then crosses the oculomotor nerve to enter the orbit through the superior orbital fissure to exclusively supply the contralateral superior oblique muscle.

The main actions of superior oblique are

  • Depression in adducted position- The muscle elevates the posterior of the eye causing the front of the eye to be depressed. Patients with trochlear nerve palsy have difficulty in looking downwards when eyes are in the adducted position. 
  • Abduction
  • Intortion of the eyeball.

Other options- Oculomotor (CN III), trigeminal (CN V) and abducens (CN VI) nerves exit ventrally from the brainstem.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles has no action at the shoulder joint?
questions.solution:
Pectoralis minor has no action at the shoulder joint.

The pectoralis minor is an accessory muscle of inspiration, which stabilizes the scapula by pulling it anteriorly and inferiorly.  

Movements at the shoulder joint:

questions.text: The mediastinum is divided into superior and inferior by a line joining sternal angle to the ________
questions.solution:
The mediastinum is divided into superior and inferior by a line joining sternal angle to the T4-T5 intervertebral disc. 

The sternal plane is traditionally reported to pass through the intervertebral disc between the T4-T5 vertebrae posteriorly and the manubriosternal joint (sternal angle or angle of Louis) at the level of the second costal cartilage anteriorly.

Recent data place the sternal angle between the T4 vertebra and the upper half of the T5 vertebra in the majority of adults.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient is posted for abscess drainage from the ischioanal fossa. While draining the abscess, the surgeon injures the nerve present in the Alcock's canal. Which nerve is injured in the given scenario?
questions.solution:
The nerve that is injured in the given scenario is the pudendal nerve. 

The pudendal nerve arises from the ventral divisions of the 2nd, 3rd and 4th ventral sacral rami. It originates in the pelvis and enters the gluteal region via the greater sciatic foramen close to its attachment at the ischial spine. It then passes through the lesser sciatic foramen into the pudendal (Alcock's) canal. In the pudendal canal, the pudendal nerve gives off the inferior rectal nerve, perineal nerve and dorsal nerve of the penis or clitoris.

Alcock's canal is an enclosed fascia along the lateral wall of the ischioanal fossa. Its contents include:

  • Internal pudendal artery
  • Internal pudendal vein
  • Pudendal nerve

Therefore, injury to the nerve in the Alcock's canal is to the pudendal nerve.

Pudendal neuralgia is a chronic pain syndrome that occurs due to damage or irritation to the pudendal nerve. It is characterized by perineal pain which gets aggravated by sitting. The common causes are prolonged sitting, repetitive hip flexions like in sports activities, direct trauma like falls, pelvic surgeries, and radiation therapy for pelvic cancers. It can be treated with nerve protection strategies, medications like gabapentin or amitriptyline, pudendal nerve blocks or decompression surgeries.

Note: Ischioanal fossa is a wedge-shaped space on either side of the anal canal in the anorectal triangle. It has a pad of fat. The boundaries include:

  • Anterior: Posterior border of the perineal membrane
  • Posterior: Gluteus maximus muscle, sacrotuberous ligament
  • Lateral: Ischial tuberosity, obturator internus
  • Medial: Sphincter ani externus, pelvic diaphragm (levator ani).

Clinical significance:

Ischioanal fossa provides a relatively bloodless field during resection of anal cancers, therefore it is an important surgical plane.

Other options:

Option A: Obturator nerve is a branch of the lumbar plexus that emerges near the L5 vertebra. It descends within the psoas major and then on the lateral wall of the pelvis before entering the obturator foramen to enter the thigh. It has no branches in the abdomen or pelvis.

Option B: Genitofemoral nerve arises from the L1 and L2. It pierces the psoas major and emerges out on the anterior surface. It descends and crosses obliquely behind the ureter and divides into genital and femoral branches. The genital branch passes through the inguinal canal and supplies the cremaster muscle and skin of the external genitalia. The femoral branch supplies the skin of the upper part of the femoral triangle. 

Option D: Accessory obturator nerve is formed from the L3 and L4. It emerges out along the medial border and travels on the posterior surface of the superior pubic ramus. It supplies the pectineus and hip joint.

questions.text: The Actions of Sartorius include:

choices.text: Abduction and lateral rotator of thigh

questions.solution:
Sartorius

  • Longest muscle of body
  • Origin: ASIS (anterior superior iliac spine)
  • Aponeurosis of Sartorius + gracilis + semitendinosus = Pes anserinus.
  • Innervation: Femoral nerve (L2, L3)
  • Actions: Flexes the leg, and thigh on the pelvis
  • Abducts and laterally rotates the thigh

questions.text: The number of vertebrae in the vertebral column is ______.
questions.solution:
The adult vertebral column usually consists of 33 vertebral segments.

Generally, the number of vertebrae found in each segment are as follows:

  • 7 cervical
  • 12 thoracic
  • 5 lumbar
  • 5 sacral
  • 4 coccygeal

However, this total is subject to frequent variability, and there have been reports of variation between 32 and 35 vertebrae.

questions.text: Which of the following accurately describes the shape of trapezius muscle?
questions.solution:
The trapezius muscle individually is a flat, triangular muscle that extends over the back of the neck and upper thorax. When paired together, they resemble a trapezium and hence the name.

Muscles with oblique fibers are further subclassified as follows:

  1. Triangular - They are triangular in shape.
  2. Pennate - They are feather-shaped. Based on their complexity, they can have the following subtypes:
    • Unipennate - fascicles on one side of the tendon.
    • Bipennate - fascicles on two sides of the tendon.
    • Multipennate - central tendon branches into two or more branches within the muscle.
    • Circumpennate (radial) - muscle fibers converge to a central tendon in a radial fashion.

questions.text: A patient presented with weakness of the right side of the face with the loss of pain and temperature. Pain and temperature sensation of the left leg is also lost. The lesion is most likely located at?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of lateral pontine syndrome which occurs due to a lesion located at lateral pons.

Lateral pontine syndrome occurs due to the involvement of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery.

  • Ipsilateral manifestations include:
    • CN VII: Facial paralysis 
    • CN V: loss of pain and temperature sensation over the face.
    • Vestibular nerve or nucleus: Horizontal and vertical nystagmus, vertigo, nausea, vomiting, oscillopsia.
    • Auditory nerve or cochlear nucleus: Deafness, tinnitus.
    • Middle cerebellar peduncle: Ataxia of limb and gait.
  • Contralateral manifestations include:
    • Spinothalamic tract: Loss of pain and temperature sensation over the body.

 Note:

In this clinical vignette, due to the absence of characteristic features specific to lateral medullary syndrome, like dysphagia and hoarseness of voice (involvement of 9th and 10th cranial nerves), the lesion is most likely to be located at lateral pons (lateral pontine syndrome) and not lateral medulla.

Related Pearl: Medullary syndromes and Weber syndrome

Syndrome

Vessel involved

Clinical features

Vertebral artery/Anterior spinal artery

C/L loss of conscious proprioception, C/L hemiplegia, I/L tongue paralysis.

C/L loss of pain/temperature on the body, I/L loss of pain/temperature on face, Ataxia, Nystagmus, Vertigo, Horner's syndrome, dysphagia, Ipsilateral bulbar paralysis and loss of gag reflex.

questions.text: Which of the following is the longest part of the large intestine?
questions.solution:
The transverse colon is the longest part of the large intestine, measuring 50 cm in length on an average. It is intraperitoneal in location and suspended by the transverse mesocolon.

Lengths of various parts of the large intestine are as follows:

Intestinal segment

 15 to 20 cm

questions.text: Lower lateral part of arm is innervated by:
questions.solution:
The lower lateral part of the arm is innervated by a branch of the radial nerve.

Lower lateral cutaneous nerve of arm is one of the 5 branches of radial nerve in the spiral groove.

Branches in the spiral groove:

  • Lower lateral cutaneous nerve of arm
  • Posterior cutaneous nerve of forearm
  • Branch to lateral head of triceps
  • Branch to medial head of triceps
  • Branch to anconeus

Radial Nerve (Largest branch of brachial plexus) C5, 6 ,7 ,8 T1

Branches:

Extensor carpi radialis longus (ECRL) is supplied by a direct branch of radial nerve while extensor carpi radialis brevis (ECRB) is supplied by deep branch of radial nerve before it enters arcade of Frohse (prone to be injured in radial head and operations.)

Compression of radial nerve: Occur in the axilla, spiral groove, proximal forearm (posterior interosseous nerve), distal forearm (Wartenberg's syndrome)

Autonomous zone for radial nerve : Dorsum of first web space.

questions.text: A 2 week-old neonate developed meningitis following a scalp abscess. What is the likely route of spread?
questions.solution:
The infection has likely spread from the sub-aponeurotic tissue. 

The sub-aponeurotic loose areolar tissue of the scalp is referred to as the dangerous area of the scalp. Infection from this layer can pass into the cranial cavity through small emissary veins, which pass through parietal foramina in the calvaria. It can reach intracranial structures causing meningitis and intracranial abscesses. 

The scalp is a soft tissue that covers the calvaria of the skull. It consists of five layers (Mnemonic- SCALP):

  1. Skin
  2. Connective tissue (superficial fascia) with blood vessels and nerves
  3. Aponeurosis (galea aponeurotica) with occipitofrontalis muscle
  4. Loose areolar (sub-aponeurotic) tissue
  5. Pericranium

questions.text: Which is a component of homeostatic control system?
questions.solution:
Stimulus, receptor and effector are all components of a homeostatic control system.

Components of homeostasis include:

  • Stimulus - It is a detectable change in the internal or external environment, such as change in temperature.
  • Receptor - It detects environmental changes.
  • Integrating centre
  • Effector - It is an organ or cell that acts in response to a stimulus.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about chemical synapses?
questions.solution:
Unidirectional conduction is a feature of chemical synapses. 

There are two types of synapses:

Chemical synapse:

The first neuron secretes a neurotransmitter at its nerve ending synapse, which acts on receptors of the next neuron to excite, inhibit, or modify its sensitivity. Conduction is unidirectional (one-way conduction). This one-way signal ensures that the signal is directed towards a specific goal. A synaptic cleft of 200-300 Å or 20-30nm separates the neurons.  The presynaptic membrane contains transmitter vesicles that contain the neurotransmitter. It does not have gap junctions. Examples of neurotransmitters is acetylcholine, norepinephrine, epinephrine, histamine, gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), and glycine. 

Electrical synapse:

The cytoplasms of adjacent cells are directly connected by clusters of ion channels called gap junction channels. There is free movement of ions from one cell to the next cell. The conduction is bidirectional and the intercellular gap is 20-40Å or 2-4nm. The bidirectional transmission of electrical synapses permits them to coordinate the activities of large groups of interconnected neurons. Electrical synapses are present in the cardiac uscles and visceral smooth muscles.

questions.text: Which of the following sleep disorder does not  occur in stage 3 of NREM
questions.solution:
Bruxism occurs in stage 2 of NREM, whereas other sleep disorders given in the option  occur in stage 3 of NREM

Related Pearl: Events occurring in NREM and REM sleep

Events occurring during NREM stages 3 and 4:

Events

Description

Somnambulism

Sleepwalking

Sleep terror or Night terror

Also called Pavor nocturnus.

Awakens with a scream or intense anxiety. Has increased autonomic disturbances.

They do not have a memory of this when they wake up.

Runs in families and seen more frequently in childhood and boys.

Treatment with benzodiazepines is rarely required.

Nocturnal enuresis

Behavioral therapy is the mainstay.

Drugs like desmopressin and imipramine are used.

 

Events occurring in REM sleep:

Events

Description

Nightmares

Fearful sleep without autonomic disturbances that are well remembered in the morning.

TCAs may be used for treatment.

Nocturnal penile tumescence

A normal phenomenon that can be used to differentiate between psychogenic and organic impotence.

Narcolepsy

A disorder of the REM sleep characterized by disturbed sleep in the night, leading to excessive sleep in the morning.

Associated with symptoms such as cataplexy, hypnogogic and hypnopompic hallucination, and sleep paralysis.

 *Hypnogogic hallucinations are those that occur at the start of sleep and hypnopompic hallucinations are those that occur at the end of sleep.

 

Others:

Events

Description

Bruxism (teeth grinding)

Occurs in stage 2 NREM sleep.

Frontal lobe epilepsy

Occurs in stage 2 NREM sleep.

Sleep talking

Occurs in all stages of sleep and may accompany night terrors and sleepwalking.

Common in children.

No treatment is necessary.

questions.text: Which of the following ions is involved in peripheral oxygen sensing chemoreceptors?
questions.solution:
Potassium is involved in peripheral oxygen sensing chemoreceptors.

Type I glomus cells (carotid and aortic body) have O2-sensitive K+ channels, whose conductance is reduced in proportion to the degree of hypoxia.

This reduces the K+ efflux, depolarizing the cell and causing Ca2+ inﬂux.

The Ca2+ influx triggers action potentials and consequent excitation of the afferent nerve endings.

questions.text: Hering's nerve finally relays in ______.
questions.solution:
The Hering's nerve terminates in the medulla (Tractus solitarius).

Baroreceptor reflexes

  • Carotid baroreceptors → Hering's nerve → the glossopharyngeal nerve → Tractus solitarius in medulla.
  • Aortic baroreceptors → Vagus nerve → tractus solitarius in medulla

questions.text: Double Bohr effect occurs in which of the following circulation?
questions.solution:
The double Bohr effect occurs in placental circulation.

The Bohr effect explains the shift of the oxygen hemoglobin association curve with respect to changes in the PCO2 and H+ levels.

The production of CO2 increases as the metabolic activity of tissues increases. This CO2 diffuses into the blood and in turn, raises the blood H2CO3 and causes an increase in the H+ concentration and a decrease in pH.

This decreases the affinity of Hb for O2, shifting the oxygen hemoglobin dissociation curve to the right. This facilitates the delivery of O2 in the tissues. This effect of PCO2 and pH on the oxygen hemoglobin dissociation curve is called the Bohr Effect.

Conversely, in the lungs, CO2 diffuses from the blood to the alveoli, the H+ concentration decreases, and the O2 hemoglobin dissociation curve shifts to the left increasing the affinity of Hb to O2.

Oxygen–hemoglobin dissociation curve (OHDC) of fetal blood and maternal blood move in opposite directions. 

In the placenta, the fetal blood entering the placenta carries large amounts of carbon dioxide, but most of it diffuses from the fetal blood into the maternal blood. This loss of CO2 makes a reduction in H+ that leads to a shift of OHDC to left. This enhances the uptake of oxygen by the fetal blood from the maternal blood. 

The increase in CO2 in maternal blood makes it more acidic. This results in releasing of oxygen from the maternal blood to the fetal blood due to the shift of OHDC to right. 

The above two effects make the Bohr shift twice in the placenta as it is for oxygen exchange in the lungs, and it is called the double Bohr effect.

questions.text: Baroreceptor provides ________
questions.solution:
Baroreceptors provide negative feedback in response to an increase in blood pressure.

Increased baroreceptor discharge inhibits the tonic discharge of sympathetic nerves and excites the vagal innervation of the heart.

Baroreceptor reflex

  • Increased BP → stimulation of baroreceptors → stimulation of NTS → inhibition of RVLM → inhibition of sympathetic system
  • Stimulation of NTS also stimulates CVC → parasympathetic stimulation
  • Net effect = sympathetic inhibition and parasympathetic stimulation → decreased HR and BP

NTS - Nucleus tractus solitarius

CVC - Cardiovagal center

RVLM - Rostral ventrolateral medulla

HR- Heart rate

BP - Blood pressure

questions.text: The following image shows which type of GI motility?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the migrating motor complex.

The image shows 3 phases: 

  • Phase I - quiescent period
  • Phase II - period of irregular electrical & mechanical activity
  • Phase III - ends with bursts of regular activity

This occurs during the inter-digestive period at intervals of about 100 min and passes in aboral direction at the rate of 5cm/min. Its main function is to clear intestinal contents and prepare for the next meal.

Other options:

Option a - Peristalsis is a propulsive movement, which consists of a segment of contraction behind and relaxation in front.

Option b - Segmentation and mixing helps in mixing intestinal contents with digestive juices and provides time for digestion and absorption. It consists of a segment of bowel contracting at both ends, and then a second contraction occurs in the center of the segment to force the chyme both backward and forward.

Option d - Basal Electrical Rhythm is fluctuation in the resting membrane potential of smooth muscle cells of the intestine as shown below:

questions.text: Macula densa is formed by which part of the nephron?
questions.solution:
Macula densa is formed by specialized tubular epithelial cells of the distal convoluted tubule.

The juxtaglomerular apparatus consists of the following parts:

  • Macula densa: At the end of the thick ascending limb of Henle, and at the beginning of the distal tubule, the tubular epithelial cells are specialized to form the macula densa 
  • Lacis cells: Extraglomerular mesangial cells situated between afferent and efferent arteriole.
  • Granular cells/JG cells: Modified smooth muscle cells of the afferent arteriole, they secrete renin. Fall in pressure in afferent arteriole stimulates renin release (mechanoreceptor), which, in turn, increases blood pressure.

questions.text: In tetany, hyperexcitability is due to______
questions.solution:
Hypocalcemia causes nervous system excitement and tetany.

When the ECF concentration of Ca2+ falls below normal, the nervous system becomes progressively more excitable because there is increased  membrane permeability to Na+, allowing easy initiation of action potentials. The peripheral nerve fibers become so excitable that they begin to discharge spontaneously, initiating impulses that pass to the skeletal muscles to elicit tetanic muscle contraction.

Tetany occurs usually when calcium concentration reaches 6 mg/dL.

The clinical features of hypocalcemia are:

  • Tetany: Increased peripheral neuromuscular irritability. May include perioral paresthesias, muscle spasms, and cramps.
  • Trosseau's sign: Induction of carpal spasm when the BP cuff is inflated 20 mm Hg over the systolic BP for three minutes or more.
  • Chvostek's sign: Contraction of the ipsilateral circumoral facial muscles when the facial nerve is tapped just anterior to the ear.
  • Severe hypocalcemia can cause seizures, carpopedal spasm, bronchospasm, and laryngospasm.

Treatment of the underlying condition is necessary. The patient should be reassured and rebreathing from a paper bag should be done during acute episodes.
