questions.text: β HCG is secreted by_____
questions.solution:
The placental gonadotropin in humans is called human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG).

  • hCG is a glycoprotein that contains galactose and hexos­amine.
  • It is produced by the syncytiotrophoblast of the placenta.
  • it is made up of α and β subunits.
  • hCG-α is identical to the α subunit of LH, FSH, and TSH.
  • hCG is primarily luteinizing and luteotropic and has little FSH activity.
  • Its presence in early pregnancy in urine is the basis of the various laboratory tests for pregnancy, and it can sometimes be detected in the urine as early as 14 days after conception.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man exercises at a high altitude. Which of the following changes would occur in him?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, there will be a rise in urinary bicarbonate levels if a person is observed exercising at a high altitude.

Adaptation at High Altitudes:

  • The work capacity is reduced at high altitudes and this reduction is in direct proportion to the decrease in O2 uptake.
  • Immediate exposure to low PO2 at higher altitudes stimulates the arterial chemoreceptors, and this stimulation increases alveolar ventilation.
  • This immediate increase in pulmonary ventilation upon rising to a high altitude blows off large quantities of CO2, reducing the PCO2 and increasing the pH of the body fluids causing respiratory alkalosis (not metabolic - option A). This raised pH inhibits the brain stem respiratory centre and opposes the increased ventilation. So, respiratory alkalosis will hinder maximal exercise effort.
  • To compensate for this respiratory alkalosis, kidneys reduce hydrogen ion secretion and increase bicarbonate excretion. This reduces plasma and cerebrospinal fluid bicarbonate concentration and brings the pH towards normal. It removes the inhibitory effect of alkalosis on respiration. Hence fall in blood bicarbonate facilitates the exercise effort.
  • Lactic acid levels increase which causes extreme fatigue. When there is insufficient oxygen (at high altitudes), most of the pyruvic acid is converted into lactic acid, which diffuses out of the muscle cells into the interstitial fluid and blood.

questions.text: A child with loose stools for one day presented to your OPD. On examination,  signs of dehydration were present and the child was given ORS. It facilitates glucose absorption through which of the following receptors?
questions.solution:
ORS facilitates glucose absorption through SGLT 1 (Sodium-dependent glucose co-transporter - 1). In a child with diarrhea, when oral rehydration solution is given, there is coupled absorption of sodium and glucose through SGLT -1.

Glucose transport may be active or passive.

Active transport of glucose takes place through Sodium dependent glucose transporter (SGLT 1 and 2). SGLT 1 helps in glucose absorption in the small intestine and renal tubules. SGLT 2 primarily facilitates glucose absorption in the renal tubules. 

Passive absorption of glucose occurs through facilitated diffusion. This is carried out by Glucose transporters (GLUT) 1 -7.

questions.text: Which of the following is given with iron to increase iron absorption?
questions.solution:
Ascorbic acid is given with iron to increase its absorption.

Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) forms soluble complexes with iron and reduces iron from the ferric to the ferrous state, thereby enhancing iron absorption.

Milk decreases iron absorption.

Gastric secretions increase iron absorption by dissolving the iron and allowing it to form soluble complexes with ascorbic and other substances. This helps in its reduction to the Fe2+ form. Antacid decreases the absorption of iron.

Tannins (present in tea), phytates, phosphates, and oxalates form insoluble complexes with iron and lower its absorption.

questions.text: The decrease in sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) will have the maximum effect on _______
questions.solution:
The decrease in sex hormone-binding globulin will have the maximum effect on testosterone.

Around 98% of the circulating testosterone is bound to plasma proteins such as sex hormone-binding globulin (65%) and albumin. So, the decrease in sex-hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) or gonadal steroid-binding globulin (GBG) will have the maximum effect on testosterone levels by increasing the levels of its free form.

questions.text: A person with myasthenia gravis notes increased muscle strength when he is treated with an acetylcholinesterase (AChE) inhibitor.  The basis for his improvement is due to the increase in _______

choices.text: The amount of acetylcholine (ACh) released from motor nerves
The level of ACh at the muscle end plates
The number of ACh receptors on the motor end plates
Synthesis of norepinephrine in motor nerves

questions.solution:
Treatment with AChE inhibitors (e.g., neostigmine) prevents the degradation of ACh and prolongs the action of ACh at the muscle end plate.

Myasthenia gravis:

  • It is caused by the presence of antibodies to the ACh receptor.
  • Is characterized by skeletal muscle weakness and fatigability resulting from a reduced number of ACh receptors on the muscle end plate.
  • The size of the EPP (end plate potential) is reduced.
  • Treatment with AChE inhibitors (e.g., neostigmine) prevents the degradation of ACh and prolongs the action of ACh at the muscle end plate, partially compensating for the reduced number of receptors.

questions.text: Calculate the respiratory quotient (RQ) in a patient with 50kg body weight, if the CO2 exhaled is 200ml/min and O2 consumed is 250 ml/min.
questions.solution:
The respiratory quotient is 0.8.

Respiratory Quotient is the ratio of carbon dioxide production to oxygen utilization.

In the given question, the CO2 production is 200mL/min, while the O2 consumption is 250mL/min.

Therefore,

Respiratory quotient = 200/250 = 0.8

 

The respiratory quotient (RQ) is used for determining the metabolic utilization of various foods.

  • When carbohydrates are metabolized with one molecule of oxygen, one carbon dioxide molecule is released. Therefore, the RQ of carbohydrates = 1.
  • When fats are oxidized, for every 100 molecules of oxygen consumed, 70 molecules of CO2 are released. Therefore, the RQ of fats is 0.70.
  • Similarly, the respiratory quotient for proteins is 0.80.

questions.text: Crown heel length of a 6 month old fetus would be:
questions.solution:
Crown heel length of a 6-month old fetus would be 30 cm.

According to the Rule of Hasse:

  • During the first five months of pregnancy the square root of the length gives the approx. age of the fetus in months.
  • During last five months the length in centimeters is divided by five gives the age in months.

Age of fetus in first five months = square root of the crown heel length in cm.

Age of the fetus during last 5 months of pregnancy = (Crown heel length in cm)/5

So, crown heel length = age in months × 5 i.e. 6 × 5 = 30 cm.

questions.text: A man has been arrested and booked under Sec. 304-B IPC. Which of the following offenses has he been accused of?
questions.solution:
Section 304-B of the Indian Penal Code (I.P.C)/ Section 80 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS) deals with dowry deaths.

This legal provision comes into effect when the untimely demise of a woman occurs by burns/bodily injury or any other cause apart from normal circumstances within the first 7 years of her marriage. Evidence of cruelty or harassment by her spouse or relatives of her spouse in connection with demands for dowry must be shown. An individual accused of dowry death (cognizable, non-bailable) is liable to imprisonment from 7 years to life. 

Other options - 

Option A - Death by rash or negligent act is punishable (imprisonment for up to 2 years with/without fine) by Sec. 304-A IPC. 

Option C - Culpable homicide is punishable by Sec. 299 IPC. It is an offense wherein the accused intentionally causes death or bodily injury likely to cause death.  Culpable homicide is defined under section 100 of the BNS.

Option D -  Grievous hurt is punishable by Sec. 320 IPC (Sec.116 BNS). Grievous hurt refers to any hurt that endangers life, or which causes the victim to be in severe bodily pain, or unable to follow his ordinary pursuits for a period of twenty days. This includes emasculation, permanent privation of the sight of either eye, permanent privation of the hearing of either ear, the privation of any member or joint or the destruction or permanent impairment of the power of any member or joint, permanent disfiguration of the head or face, and fracture or dislocation of a bone or tooth.

questions.text: What is the odor of the mummified body?
questions.solution: Mummified body is odourless.

questions.text: An autopsy may be performed at the site of recovery of the body in case of?
questions.solution:
An autopsy may be performed at the site of recovery of the body, in the following scenarios :

  • Advanced stage of putrefaction as materials of evidentiary value may be lost during transportation.
  • Exhumation
  • If the District Magistrate desires it to be conducted at the site due to some law and order problems.

 An autopsy is preferably performed in an equipped mortuary.

questions.text: First-hand knowledge rule is applicable to:
questions.solution:
The first-hand knowledge rule is applicable to a common witness who gives evidence about the facts observed or perceived by him.

An expert witness is someone who has been trained or is skilled or has knowledge and experience and is able to draw conclusions from the facts observed by him. Doctors, handwriting/ fingerprints/ firearms experts come under this category.

A hostile witness is a person who is supposed to have some interest or motive for concealing a part of the truth or for giving completely false evidence.

questions.text: Luminescent stools are associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
In acute poisoning with phosphorus, the vomitus and stools will be luminous in the dark. The stools may give rise to faint fumes, constituting the smoky stool syndrome.

Related Pearl: Phosphorus poisoning

Features

Phosphorus
Chemistry

2 forms - White and Red Phosphorus

White Phosphorus is toxic, Red Phosphorus is not.
Mechanism of action Protoplasmic irritant poison
Organs affected

Liver

Bone

Kidneys
Characteristic clinical findings

Smoky stool syndrome

Garlicky odor

Liver necrosis

Phossy jaw
Treatment

Symptomatic therapy

questions.text: In Breslau’s second life test, the organ tested is _______
questions.solution:
In Breslau’s second life test the organ tested is Stomach and intestine.

BRESLAU’S SECOND LIFE TEST:

  • It is based on air entering stomach and intestine during respiration in a live born foetus.
  • Stomach and intestine are removed by tying double ligatures at each end and placed in water.
  • Inference:
  • A floating viscera giving out air-bubbles when opened under water is positive test and suggestive of live birth.
  • False positive – in case of stillbirth, air might enter the stomach when child tries to free obstruction of air passages.
  • Mucus, saliva and air bubbles in stomach – breathing has occurred.
  • Only mucus – breathing has not occurred.
  • Blood, meconium, liquor amnii in stomach – child alive at or shortly before birth.
  • Milk in stomach – child was alive for sometime after birth.
  • Test is invalid in case of putrefaction.

questions.text: Etymologically, the term asphyxia literally means:
questions.solution: Etymologically, the word asphyxia means the absence of pulsation, though common usage has led the term to be equated to lack of oxygen.

questions.text: A man regularly derives sexual gratification by inflicting pain upon his partner. He would often produce cuts and cigarette burns on his partner's arms. This is best described as?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of sexual sadism. It is seen more commonly in men. It develops due to early experiences of brutality in sex.

The sadist may bite, beat, whip, produce cuts or cigarette burns etc on their sexual partner. In extreme cases, the victim's nipples may be bitten off, items such as a bottle or sticks are inserted into the vagina. Blunt trauma causing fractures and rupture of internal organs may also be seen.

Other options:

Option A - Voyeurism - It is the act of obtaining sexual gratification by observing an unsuspecting person who is naked, disrobing or engaging in sexual activity.

Option B - Fetishism - It is a form of sexual behaviour in which gratification is associated with an abnormal stimulus which may be an object, activity or part of the body.

Option D - Masochism - This is opposite to sadism. Sexual gratification is obtained by suffering the pain.

questions.text: Bullet fingerprinting involves:
questions.solution:
Bullet fingerprinting involves both primary and secondary markings.

Primary markings are formed when a bullet passes through a barrel and the sides are marked by the rifling of the barrel (which is specific to the make and model of the gun).

Irregularrities on the inner surface of barrel itself which are specific for that particular weapon are also seen on the bullet and are called secondary markings.

questions.text: The diagnosis in the audiogram shown below:
questions.solution:
The above Pure tone audiogram is characteristic of Otosclerosis.

In the above audiogram,

  • An air-bone gap is present.
  • BC > AC

This is suggestive of Conductive Hearing loss. In the above options, only Otosclerosis causes conductive hearing loss. Carhart’s notch is the characteristic dip in the BC curve at 2000 Hz seen in otosclerosis. It disappears after successful stapes surgery.

PTA in Sensorineural hearing loss :

  • Shows no Air Bone gap.
  • Both BC and AC are in hearing loss range (>25 DB)

Other options:

  • Meniere’s disease shows a low-frequency loss in the SNHL curve. 
  • Noise-induced hearing loss is SNHL and PTA shows characteristic Acoustic dip at 4000 Hz.
  • Ototoxicity causes SNHL and shows high-frequency hearing loss in the SNHL curve.

questions.text: You are evaluating the patency and function of the Eustachian tube in a patient with a right earache and ear block. Which of the following test you will not do?
questions.solution:
Stenger test is not used for the assessment of patency or function of the eustachian tube. It is used to detect malingering of hearing loss.

Tests of Eustachian tube patency:

  • Pneumatic otoscopy
  • Nasopharyngoscopy
  • Valsalva manoeuvre
  • ET catheterization
  • Politzer test.

Tests of Eustachian tube function:

  • Toynbee’s test
  • Tympanometry
  • Saccharine/dye tests in perforated ears
  • Sonotubometry.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about antrochoanal polyp except:
questions.solution:
All of the above statements about the antrochoanal polyp are true except it is bilateral.

Antrochoanal polyp is a type of non-neoplastic nasal polypoidal masses of edematous nasal or sinus mucosa. It arises from the mucosa of the maxillary antrum near its accessory ostium, comes out of it, and grows in the choana and nasal cavity. It is usually single and unilateral that are more commonly seen in children and young adults. 

The clinical features include unilateral nasal obstruction, mucoid nasal discharge, and a hyponasal voice. Anterior rhinoscopy may miss the antrochoanal polyp when it starts to grow posteriorly. A large polyp may protrude from the nasal cavity and may appear pink and congested.  

Diagnosis: Radiograph of the paranasal sinuses reveals opacity of the involved antrum. Non-contrast CT scan reveals the extent of the polyp. Endoscopic examination reveals the antrochoanal polyp hidden posteriorly in the nasal cavity

Treatment: Endoscopic sinus surgery is the treatment of choice. Recurrence is uncommon after the complete removal of the polyp.

questions.text: Endoscopic nasal surgery is used to access all of the following structures except
questions.solution: Apart from nose and paranasal sinuses, endoscopic surgery can be used to access orbit, optic nerve, lacrimal sac, pituitary but not cerebellum.

questions.text: Which of the following marked blood vessels is the main arterial supply of palatine tonsils?
questions.solution:
The main arterial supply of tonsil is by the tonsillar branch of the facial artery which is represented by the marked blood vessel "3" in the given image.

Other blood vessels marked in the image are 

1 - Descending palatine branch of the maxillary artery

2 - Tonsillar branch of the ascending pharyngeal artery

4 - Dorsal lingual branches of the lingual artery

Five arteries supply the tonsil:

  1. Tonsillar branch of the facial artery (the main artery)
  2. Ascending palatine branch of the facial artery
  3. Ascending pharyngeal branch of the external carotid artery
  4. Dorsal lingual branches of the lingual artery
  5. Descending palatine branches of the maxillary artery

questions.text: Factor implicated in the high incidence of Nasopharyngeal Ca in China
questions.solution:
The Chinese have a very high incidence of NPC. The following factors have been implicated in the pathogenesis:

  • Burning of incense or wood (polycyclic hydrocarbon)
  • Use of preserved salted fish (nitrosamines)
  • Vitamin C deficient diet (vitamin C blocks nitrosification of amines and is thus protective)

questions.text: The recurrent laryngeal nerve supplies all except______
questions.solution:
Cricothyroid is the only intrinsic muscle of the larynx that is supplied by the superior laryngeal nerve.

All other muscles are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

questions.text: A 65-year-old trumpet player presents with hoarseness of voice, cough, and neck swelling as shown in the image below. The swelling increases in size on coughing and performing Valsalva maneuver. On pressing the swelling, a gurgling sound is heard. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is laryngocele.

The given clinical scenario of hoarseness of voice, cough, neck swelling that increases in size on coughing/Valsalva maneuver and a gurgling sound heard on pressing the swelling are suggestive of laryngocele.

Laryngocele is an air-filled cystic swelling in the neck due to dilatation of the saccule. It is more commonly seen in trumpet players, glass-blowers, or weight lifters due to a raised transglottic air pressure in these people. It can be divided into internal, external, or combined types of laryngocele.

  • Internal laryngocele is limited within the larynx and appears as distension of the false cord and aryepiglottic fold
  • External laryngocele has a distended saccule that herniates through the thyrohyoid membrane and appears as a swelling in the neck
  • Combined or mixed laryngocele has both internal and external laryngoceles as its components

Given below is a diagrammatic representation of laryngocele

Laryngocele presents with hoarseness of voice, cough, and airway obstruction (if large). External laryngocele presents as a reducible swelling in the neck that increases in size on coughing or performing Valsalva maneuver. On pressing the neck swelling, a gurgling sound is heard indicative of a positive Bryce's sign. Adult laryngoceles can be associated with carcinoma.

Diagnosis is based on an indirect laryngoscopy and CT scan. CT scan reveals the extent of the lesion.

Treatment: Internal laryngocele is managed by marsupialization and surgical excision is done through an external neck incision for external laryngocele.

Other options:

Option A- Thyroglossal cyst is a midline cystic swelling usually affecting younger children. It can also occur at any age. It arises from the thyroglossal duct and can occur anywhere along the course of the thyroglossal duct. This swelling moves along with tongue protrusion as the thyroglossal duct is attached to the foramen caecum at the base of the tongue. It is managed by performing a Sistrunk operation.

The below image shows a patient with a thyroglossal cyst.

Option C: Zenker's diverticulum is a pulsion diverticulum in which the pharyngeal mucosa is herniated through the Killian's dehiscence (a weak area between the 2 parts of the inferior constrictor). It usually occurs due to the uncoordinated contraction or the spasm of the cricopharyngeal sphincter during deglutition. Dysphagia is the predominant feature with a gurgling sound produced on swallowing. Regurgitation of the undigested food and aspiration pneumonia are also seen. Barium swallow reveals the sac and its size.

The below image shows the Zenker's diverticulum on the barium swallow. 

Option D- Cystic hygroma occurs due to obstruction of the jugular lymph sac. It is most commonly seen in the posterior triangle of the neck. More than 90% of the cases occur before the age of 2 years. It can result in stridor, respiratory difficulty, or feeding problems. It is partially compressible and brilliantly transilluminant.

The below image shows cystic hygroma in a child.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument:
questions.solution:
The image is of a tympanometer. It is used in evaluating the status of middle ear.

It is based on a simple principle that when a sound strikes tympanic membrane, some of the sound energy is absorbed while the rest is reflected. A stiffer tympanic membrane would reflect more of sound energy than a compliant one. By changing the pressures in a sealed external auditory canal and then measuring the reflected sound energy, it is possible to find the compliance or stiffnessof the tympano-ossicular system and thus find the healthy or diseased status of the middle ear.

By charting the compliance of tympano-ossicular system against various pressure changes, different types of graphs called tympanograms is as follows:

questions.text: Jack knife position causes death due to:
questions.solution: Jack knife position is a position where victim's thighs and knees are driven against chest causing indirect compression of chest and restriction of breathing movements leading to Positional asphyxia.

questions.text: Which of the following causes opening of eustachian tube?
questions.solution:
Eustachian tube is closed at rest & opens intermittently during swallowing/yawning/sneezing.

Opening of the tube

  • The medial fibres of the tensor veli palatini are attached to the lateral lamina of the tube and contract  to open the tubal lumen. They are also called dilator tubae muscle.
  • Accessory muscles for opening are Levator veli palatine & Salpingopharyngeus

Closure of the tube

  • It is mainly due to elastic recoil of the cartilage aided by the high degree of elastin on the roof.

Ostmann’s pad of fat helps to keep the tube closed.

questions.text: A patient undergoes surgery of the lateral part of the base of the skull. Postoperatively, the patient presents with aspiration but does not have a change in voice. Which of the following is the reason?
questions.solution:
The patient has an injury of the Superior Laryngeal Nerve.

In SLN supplies, only the cricothyroid muscle which is used only in high-pitch vocalization, so in SLN injury normal speech will not be affected. SLN also provides sensory supply to the mucosa above vocal cords, hence it's lesion would lead to increased susceptibility to aspiration.

The patient presents with aspiration, which rules out glossopharyngeal nerve as an option here since it doesn't provide either sensory or motor supply to the larynx and therefore it's lesion wouldn't cause aspiration.

The patient has normal vocalization which rules out RLN and high vagal injury. RLN supplies all the intrinsic muscles of the larynx except cricothyroid, therefore an RLN lesion would lead to disordered vocalization. A high vagal injury would mean both the SLN and RLN functions are affected, therefore that can also be ruled out.

questions.text: Sudden death during antral lavage can be due to
questions.solution:
Air embolism is rare but fatal complication that can occur during antral lavage.

This complication can be prevented by avoiding insufflation of air into the antrum after lavage.

questions.text: Which of the following complications would you not expect to see in a patient diagnosed with diphtheria?
questions.solution:
Hard palate paralysis is not seen in diphtheria.

The exotoxin produced by C. diphtheriae is toxic to the heart and nerves. It causes:

  • Myocarditis
  • Cardiac arrhythmias
  • Acute circulatory failure

Neurological complications include paralysis of the soft-palate, diaphragm, and ocular muscles. In the larynx, the diphtheric membrane may cause airway obstruction.

questions.text: Temporary Tarsorrhaphy is done for_____
questions.solution:
Exposure keratitis is one of the most common and morbid complications of the Facial palsy:

  • Due to inability to close eyes, tear film dries up
  • Treatment is with artificial tears and eye ointment and covers during the night.
  • If prolonged, temporary tarsorrhaphy is indicated with heavy implants.

questions.text: Majority of the energy requirement in the lens is met by the ______________.
questions.solution:
• 90–95 % of the glucose that enters the lens is converted to glucose 6 phosphate by hexokinase.
    • The remaining 5% is converted to sorbitol and gluconic acid.
  • Glucose 6 phosphate formed is metabolized in 3 ways: 
    • Glycolysis: 80 %
    • Pentose phosphate pathway: 10%
    • TCA cycle: 3%
  • Energy in the lens is stored in the form of ATP.

questions.text: A  22 year old girl enquires if there are any surgical options for the correction of her myopia. She does not wish to wear her glasses anymore, nor does she wish to switch to contact lenses. What is the minimum time frame for which her refractive error has to be stable before laser assisted in-situ keratomileusis (LASIK) can be considered for her?
questions.solution:
The patient's refractive error has to be stable for a minimum period of atleast 1 year before undergoing laser assisted in-situ keratomileusis. (LASIK)

Laser-assisted in situ keratomileusis (LASIK) is performed using excimer laser. It is the surgery of choice for myopia. 

Excimer laser beam reshapes the cornea by ablating the superficial stroma to a predetermined extent after lifting a flap of the cornea with a sharp
microkeratome. 

Steps: microkeratome cut, laser photoablation with flap lifted, flap repositioning.

Patient selection criteria:

  • In individuals aged 21 years and above.
  • In individuals who have a stable refractive error for atleast 1 year.
  • In individuals who have had unsatisfactory results with non-surgical treatment.
  • In individuals in whom corneal-thinning disorders such as keratoconus have been ruled out.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the image given below?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a pinguecula.

They are elevated, white to yellow in color, horizontally oriented areas of bulbar conjunctival thickening that adjoin the limbus in the palpebral fissure area. 

They have a fatty appearance.

They are usually bilateral

They are more often located nasally than temporally.

  • Treatment
    • Pingueculitis responds to a brief course of NSAIDs or topical corticosteroids 
    • Simple excision may be warranted in rare cases, wherein pingueculae may be chronically inflamed or cosmetically unsatisfactory.

questions.text: Where is the thickest part of sclera located?

choices.text: Anterior to attachment of the superior rectus

questions.solution:
The sclera is thickest (about 1 mm) in the area around optic nerve.

It is thinnest at the insertions of extra-ocular muscles.

questions.text: Labrador keratopathy occurs due  to ________.
questions.solution:
Labrador keratopathy occurs due to exposure to UV rays.

Labrador keratopathy/spheroidal degeneration/climatic droplet keratopathy

  • It typically occurs in men whose working lives are spent outdoors.
  • Cause: due to exposure to UV rays
  • Histology: Irregular proteinaceous deposits in the anterior stroma that replace the Bowman layer.

 

Image: Labrador keratopathy

questions.text: A preterm baby in the neonatal intensive care unit is being screened for retinopathy of prematurity (ROP). She is found to have stage 2 ROP in zone I with no plus disease.  What is the recommended treatment for this stage of the disease?
questions.solution:
The recommended treatment for ROP stage 2 in zone I (categorized as type I/low-risk ROP) is careful observation and follow-up.

Retinopathy of prematurity occurs in premature infants with low birth weight, with a typical history of exposure to oxygen in high concentrations leading to bilateral proliferative retinopathy. 

Stages of Retinopathy of Prematurity:

  • Stage 1- demarcation line formation at the edge of vessels, dividing the vascular from the avascular retina.
  • Stage 2- intraretinal ridge formation
  • Stage 3- ridge with extraretinal fibrovascular proliferation into the vitreous.
  • Stage 4- subtotal retinal detachment
  • Stage 5- total retinal detachment
  • 'Plus' disease is characterized by dilatation and tortuosity of blood vessels in at least two quadrants of the posterior fundus. It signifies the progression of the disease.

Location:

Zone I: Circular area with a radius twice the distance from disc to the fovea, with the disc as the center. (as shown in the image)
Zone II: It covers the area beyond zone I circumferentially till nasal ora serrata.
Zone III: It consists of residual temporal crescent anterior to zone II.

These zones are shown in the image below:

 

Treatment is based on guidelines set by the early treatment of retinopathy of prematurity trial (ETROP).

Type 1: Treatment within 72 hours (High risk)

  • Any ROP + plus disease
  • Stage 3 ROP in zone I
  • Stage 2/3 in zone II + plus disease.

Type 2: Observation (Low risk)

  • Stage 1/2 in zone I only and no plus disease
  • Stage 3 ROP within zone II and no plus disease.

This can be summarized in the table below:

    Stage 1   Stage 2   Stage 3
Zone I Observation Observation Treatment
Zone II - without plus disease   Observation  Observation
Zone II- with plus disease   Treatment Treatment

 

ROP of any stage in any zone, if associated with 'plus' disease, should receive treatment urgently.

Treatment includes laser ablation of the avascular peripheral retina, anti-VEGF medication (bevacizumab), and pars plana vitrectomy for advanced disease. The high-risk patients requiring treatment should receive it within 72 hours.

questions.text: The drug of choice for inverse glaucoma is ______
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for inverse glaucoma is atropine.

Inverse glaucoma is a type of pupillary block glaucoma (secondary angle closure glaucoma), which is aggravated by miotics and relieved by mydriatic and cycloplegic agents.

Causes of inverse glaucoma include:

  • Malignant glaucoma
  • Anteriorly dislocated lens of Weill–Marchesani syndrome

questions.text: The structure marked as "A" in the image below is derived from -
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is the Crystalline Lens. It is derived from the Surface Ectoderm.

The image below is the cross-section of the eye.

Embryological Development of the Eye

By approximately day 22, 2 small grooves appear on either side of the developing forebrain in the neural folds, these are called optic grooves. As the neural tube closes, these grooves develop outpouchings called optic vesicles. These optic vesicles extend from the forebrain to the surface ectoderm.

Some pathology that occurs in the lens during the developmental stages:

  • Developmental cataract: Punctate, Zonular, Fusiform, Nuclear, Coronary, Anterior Capsular (Polar), Posterior Capsular (Polar) cataracts
  • Coloboma of the lens (notch-shaped defect in the inferior margin)
  • Cataract associated with anterior persistent primary vitreous (PHPV)
  • Spherophakia, microphakia, microspherophakia (variations in the shape of the lens)
  • Lenticonus (abnormal curvature)
  • Ectopia lentis (congenital dislocation or subluxation of the lens)

questions.text: Most common lid malignancy in HIV patient:
questions.solution:
Kaposi sarcoma is the commonest malignancy of the lid and conjunctiva in HIV patients.

It appears as a violaceous non-tender nodule on the eyelid or conjunctiva. It is a rapidly growing acquired neoplasm composed of malignant stromal cells densely vascularized by blood vessels of capillary size.

The typical lesion appears as an expanding, bright red subepithelial mass that projects through and replaces the overlying conjunctival epithelium. Spontaneous bleeding leading to bloody tears or a subconjunctival hematoma is relatively common.

Conjunctival Kaposi’s sarcoma can be treated by

  • Excision
  • Cryotherapy
  • Radiation therapy (external beam or contact therapy)
  • Chemotherapy or
  • Topical or intralesional interferon-α.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female patient came with complaints of floaters and blurring of vision in both eyes for a few weeks.  Fundoscopic examination shows inferior snow banking.  What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a young female presenting with floaters, blurring of vision, and fundoscopy showing snow banking is suggestive of intermediate uveitis or pars planitis

Intermediate uveitis is the inflammation involving pars plana ciliaris, peripheral retina, choroid, and vitreous base. It is predominantly seen in young females and most often presents with floaters and bilateral blurring of vision.

Snow banking is the hallmark of intermediate uveitis. It refers to greyish white fibrovascular plaques over the pars plana, with or without peripheral retinal periphlebitis. This occurs due to the coalescence of snowball opacities.

Other Signs of intermediate uveitis:

  • Snow-ball opacities (Ant’s egg opacities)- typical exudates present near the ora Serrata in the inferior quadrant
  • Few keratic precipitates (KP) due to spillover anterior uveitis

Other options:

Option A: Anterior uveitis or iridocyclitis is the inflammation of tissue from the iris up to the pars plicata of the ciliary body. It is the most common form of uveitis. They present with:

  • Circumcorneal conjunctival hyperemia
  • Aqueous flare  
  • Keratin precipitates (KPs) 
  • Posterior synechiae  

Option C: Posterior uveitis is the inflammation of the choroid with or without inflammation of the retina. They are classified as:

  • Choroiditis  
  • Chorioretinitis  
  • Retinochoroditis  
  • Neuroretinitis  

Option D: Fuchs' uveitis or Fuchs heterochromatic iridocyclitis is a chronic non-granulomatous condition. They are usually unilateral. A difference in color between the iris of both eyes termed heterochromia iridis is characteristically seen here. Posterior synechiae are absent. A characteristic stellate-shaped keratic precipitates are located diffusely over the entire corneal epithelium.

questions.text: Holmgren's wool-matching test is used for the assessment of ________.
questions.solution:
Holmgren's wool-matching test is used for the assessment of color vision.

Tests for color vision

    • There are 38 plates read at a distance of 75 cm.
    • Drawback: Cannot detect blue color defect

Image: Ishihara pseudo-isochromatic chart

  • Hardy–Rand–Rittler test
  • City University test
  • Holmgrens wool-matching test
  • Naegels anamoloscope
  • Farnsworth Munsell 100 hue test

questions.text: An 8-week-old child presents with watering and discharge of the eye. On eye examination, anterior and posterior chamber findings were normal. On performing the fluorescein dye disappearance test, the dye that is placed into the inferior cul-de-sac does not drain from the nose within 5 minutes. Which of the following is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of a congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction (NLDO). The treatment of choice is massaging over the lacrimal sac. This is also known as Criggler's massage.

 

Crigler’s massage increases the hydrostatic pressure and is used in the management of Congenital Nasolacrimal Duct Obstruction.

questions.text: All are ocular manifestations of dengue except ________.
questions.solution:
Cataract is not an ocular manifestation of dengue.

Potential pathogenic mechanisms include a direct viral effect on the eye, an immune-mediated vasculitis, and/or a variety of secondary effects related to dengue-induced vascular leakage and hemostatic derangements.

Ocular manifestations of dengue:

  • Typically, patients complain of painless visual impairment within 1 week from illness onset, often around the time of the platelet nadir.
  • Conjunctival injection and subconjunctival hemorrhage.
  • Complications such as retinal hemorrhage, retinal edema, macular ischemia, macular edema, vitreous hemorrhage, vitritis, and optic neuritis or papillitis
  • Depending on the severity of the ocular lesion, gradual improvement in vision occurs over several weeks, although in rare cases permanent visual impairment may result.

questions.text: Identify the finding marked by the arrow in the below image.
questions.solution:
The finding given in the image is that of a Vossius ring.

Vossius ring is a circular ring of faint or stippled opacity, seen on the anterior surface of the lens due to brown amorphous granules of pigment lying on the capsule of the lens. It is usually seen after blunt trauma to the eye and orbit.

It usually has about the same diameter as the contracted pupil. The force of the blow drives the cornea and iris backward and thus producing an impression of the iris on the lens. The resorption of the pigment results in discrete subcapsular opacities.

Other options:

Option B: Weiss ring is a floater which may be seen by the patient as a circle or other large solitary lesion. It is the detached former attachment to the margin of the optic disc. It is seen in posterior vitreous detachment and is not confirmatory. It is seen in the image below.

Option C: A Fleischer's ring is usually observed in keratoconus, representing epithelial iron deposits. It is seen best with a cobalt blue filter.

Option D: Kayser-Fleischer ring is observed in Wilson's disease, due to intraocular deposition of copper. A brownish-yellow zone is seen in the peripheral Descemet membrane of the cornea. Anterior capsular cataract, also knowns as a sunflower cataract may be seen in some patients.

questions.text: All are uses of stenopaeic slit except ____________.

choices.text: To find out the axis in astigmatism

questions.solution:
Stenopaeic slit is not used in corneal tattooing.

Uses of stenopaeic slit test:

  • Fincham’s test: to differentiate between the colored halos due to cataract and corneal edema due to glaucoma
  • To find out the optimal site for optical iridectomy in case of corneal opacities
  • To find out the axis in astigmatism

Related Pearl: Fincham’s Test

Also called Emsley–Fincham Test

It used for differentiating between the colored halos due to cataract and the colored halos in corneal edema due to glaucoma. It is performed by passing a stenopaic slit across the pupil and observing the halos.

Halos are broken up into segments which revolve as the slit moves → Lenticular halo

Intact halos but the intensity and brightness are diminished → Glaucomatous halo due to fluid accumulation in the corneal epithelium

The image shows a stenopaeic slit

It causes

  • Reduced size of blur circle in the meridian perpendicular to the slit.
  • No change in the blur circle in the meridian coincident with it.

So, it can be used to determine the axis of the cylinder in astigmatism.

In cases with corneal opacity, the optimal site for optical iridectomy is determined using a stenopaic slit.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about ICD- 11?

choices.text: It includes a new chapter on traditional medicine.
Gender incongruence is now listed as part of mental health.
The codes relating to antimicrobial resistance are more closely in line with the Global  Antimicrobial Resistance Surveillance System (GLASS).
It will come into full effect on January 2022.

questions.solution:
The new ICD-11 has a new chapter on sexual health that contains gender incongruence, which was previously listed under mental health conditions in the ICD-10.

The ICD 11 was released by the WHO in June, 2018 and was presented at the World Health Assembly in May 2019 for adoption by Member States, and will come into effect on 1 January 2022.

Its designations for antibiotic resistance align with the Global Antimicrobial Resistance Surveillance System (GLASS).

New chapters on

  • Traditional medicine
  • Sexual health: Gender incongruence has been moved from mental health to sexual health.
  • Gaming disorder has been added under Addictive disorders.
  • Immune system disorders, which will enable better study of allergies.

It has more detail on cancer, specifically different types of skin cancer, as well as on heart health and weight disorders.

questions.text: A soldier underwent a left below-knee amputation after a  terrorist attack with explosives. He was brought to your department for fixing the below prosthesis.   Which level of prevention does this fall under?
questions.solution:
Strategies to reduce impairment with prostheses fall under the tertiary level of prevention. 

Tertiary prevention includes all rehabilitation measures available to reduce or limit impairments and disabilities, and minimize suffering caused by any stage of the disease. This also promotes the patient's adjustment to irremediable conditions. Tertiary prevention extends the concepts of prevention by rehabilitation.

Examples include occupational and physical therapy in burn patients, and cardiac rehabilitation in post-myocardial infarction patients.

Other options:

Option B- Secondary prevention includes early disease detection, and its target is healthy-appearing individuals with subclinical forms of the disease. This is defined as the action which halts the progress of the disease at its incipient stage and prevents complications. Screening tests and early diagnosis are the specific interventions used in the secondary level of prevention and they help to arrest the disease process.  

Option C- Primary prevention is defined as an action taken before the onset of disease, which removes the possibility that a disease will ever occur. Primary prevention is obtained by measures promoting general health and well-being, and the quality of life of people by specific protective measures. This helps in the modification of risk factors of a disease.  

Option D- Primordial prevention consists of risk factor reduction targeted towards an entire population through a focus on social and environmental conditions. Measures taken in this level of prevention are typically promoted through laws and national policies. The main intervention in primordial prevention is by individual and mass education.

questions.text: Observe the following curves, which of the following is true statement about sensitivity and specificity when the curve changes from green to pink?
questions.solution:
The true statement is both sensitivity and specificity increase.

Sensitivity: Proportion of all people with disease who test positive, or the probability that when the disease is present, the test is positive.
Sensitivity = TP / (TP + FN) or Sensitivity = 1 – false-negative rate

Specificity: Proportion of all people without disease who test negative, or the probability that when the disease is absent, the test is negative.
Specificity= TN / (TN + FP) or specificity= 1 – false-positive rate

In this question, switching from green to pink increases number of true positive and true negatives and decreases false positive and negatives.
Hence leading to increased sensitivity and specificity.

Related Pearl: Cut-off points in diagnostic tests

  • Highly sensitive test, when negative, rules out a disease. (Screening test)
  • Highly specific test, when positive, rules in a disease. (Confirmatory test)

Sensitivity (True-positive rate): High sensitivity indicates low false-negative rate.

Specificity (True-negative rate): High specificity indicates low false-positive rate.

questions.text: Hydrogen peroxide is ______
questions.solution:
Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) is bactericidal, fungicidal, sporicidal and virucidal.

It is a high-level disinfectant.

Sporicidal activities require higher concentrations and longer contact times.

questions.text: A Ph.D scholar wants to study the etiological factors leading to the development of Moebius syndrome. Which study design should she use?
questions.solution:
Moebius syndrome is a rare disease so a case-control study should be used by the researcher to study the etiology of this disease.

The case-control study is a comparison or cross-reference study with individuals as the unit of study. It is also called a retrospective study. It is a good analytical design to study rare diseases. This study is the first approach to test causal hypotheses.

The case-control method has three distinct features:

  1. Both exposure and outcome (disease) have occurred before the start of the study
  2. The study proceeds backward from effect to cause
  3. It uses a control/comparison group to support/reject an inference 

Other options:

Option A - Cohort study is a follow-up study with individuals as the unit of study. It is used for the study of multiple outcomes related to exposure of study. It can not be used when the exposure under investigation is rare.

Option B - Cross-sectional study is a prevalence study with individuals as the unit of study. It is also known as a prevalence study and is more useful for the study of chronic diseases. It is more appropriate for the study of the distribution of a disease in a population than studying its etiology.

Option D - Ecological study is a correlational study with the population as the unit of study.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is called the 8th day disease?
questions.solution: Tetanus is known as the 8th day disease in Punjab, as the first symptom is seen about the 7th day after birth due to infection of the umbilical stump.

questions.text: Which of the following maximally affect the positive predictive value of a test?
questions.solution:
Positive predictive value (PPV) is maximally affected by the prevalence of the disease.

If the prevalence of a disease in a population is high, the high will be the positive predictive value of a screening test, and the more accurate will be the test. If the prevalence declines, the PPV will be low.

PPV is directly proportional to the prevalence of a disease. It is affected the most by prevalence. However, both sensitivity and specificity can change the predictive value.

questions.text: Where is the National Tuberculosis Institute located?
questions.solution:
National Tuberculosis Institute is located in Bangalore.

Important national centers for tuberculosis in India:

  • Tuberculosis Research Center: Chennai
  • National Tuberculosis Institute: Bangalore

questions.text: World AIDS day is on_______
questions.solution: The world AIDS day is designated on 1st December every year since 1988, is dedicated to raising awareness of the AIDS pandemic caused by the spread of HIV infection and mourning those who have died of the disease.

questions.text: You are an intern in the pediatrics outpatient department. An overweight child, suspected of obesity is brought for assessment of body fat. The consultant on duty asks you to measure the skinfold thickness of the child. Which of the following regions are not measured for skinfold thickness?
questions.solution:
The mid-thigh region is not measured for skinfold thickness.

The assessment of skinfold thickness measures the amount of subcutaneous fat. Measurement of skinfold thickness is done as it is easily accessible. It is a rapid and non-invasive method for assessing body fat. The callipers used for this purpose is called Harpenden skin calliper. 

Measurements are taken from the following four sites :

  1. Mid-triceps region
  2. Biceps region
  3. Subscapular region
  4. Suprailiac region

The sum of the measurements should be less than 40 mm in boys and 50 mm in girls. 

Disadvantages- Standards for subcutaneous fat do not exist for comparison. In extreme obesity, measurements cannot be taken. It  has poor repeatability.

Other indicators of body fat include :

  • Body weight
  • Waist circumference and waist-hip ratio
  • Total body water
  • Total body potassium
  • Body density

questions.text: A child on examination has Bitot’s spots. It belongs to the WHO class ______
questions.solution:
Bitot's spots belongs to WHO class X1 B.

Primary signs

  • X3 B-Corneal ulceration (more than 1/3 of cornea)

Secondary signs

  • XN-Night blindness
  • XF-fundal changes
  • XS-corneal scarring

questions.text: A patient has rheumatic fever with carditis without any residual damage to the valve. What will be the duration of penicillin prophylaxis in him?
questions.solution:
A patient rheumatic fever with carditis without any residual damage to the valve is given a penicillin prophylaxis for 10 years.

Recommendations for duration of secondary penicillin prophylaxis:

Category of the patient

Duration of prophylaxis

Rheumatic fever without carditis

For 5 years after the last attack or until 21 years of age ( whichever is longer)

Rheumatic fever with carditis but with no residual valvular disease

For 10 years after the last attack or until 21 yrs of age (whichever is longer)

Rheumatic fever with persistent valvular disease evident clinically or on echo

For 10 years after the last attack or until 40 years of age, or sometimes lifelong prophylaxis

questions.text: Blood pressure of a person on day 1 was 142/90 mm of Hg. After 2 days the blood pressure of the same person measured with the same apparatus under the same emotional and physical state of the person by different doctor reads 160/98. Which error is mainly responsible for this reading?
questions.solution:
Observer errors arise due to difference in hearing acuity and interpretation of korotkoff sounds.

The types of errors identified in the measurement of blood pressures:

  • Observer errors - due to difference in hearing acuity, interpretation of korotkoff sounds.
  • Instrumental errors - due to a leaking valve or cuffs that do not encircle the arm completely.
  • Subject errors - due to the anxiety, fear, etc.

questions.text: The weight of a diabetic woman is 75 kg and her  height is 150 cm. Calculate her BMI.
questions.solution:
The BMI of an individual with a weight of 75 kg and height of 150 cm is 33. It is calculated as follows,

BMI = Weight (in kg) / Height2 (in metre2) = 75 / (1.5)2 = 33.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a leading cause of death in the 1-4 years age group in countries with below population pyramid?
questions.solution:
The given population pyramid shows a bulge in the middle and has a narrower base and is suggestive of developed countries. Diarrheal disease is not a leading cause of death in the 1-4 years age group in developed countries whereas all other options are the leading causes of death in this group. 

Diarrheal disease, respiratory infection followed by communicable diseases like whooping cough and measles are the leading cause of death in 1-4 years of age children. When these diseases are combined with malnutrition, they have high case fatality rates. 

Infectious diseases are quite rare in developed countries. Accidental deaths are the leading cause of death from the age of one year. Identified groups of home accidents are:

  • Fall from unprotected stairs and balconies
  • Suffocation
  • Burns and scalds
  • Poisoning

Most accidents are preventable. Other leading causes are congenital anomalies and malignant neoplasms. These are not easy to prevent or cure. 

Leading cause of death in 1-4 years of age group
Developing countries Developed countries
Diarrhea Accidents
Respiratory infection Congenital anomalies
Malnutrition Malignant neoplasm
Infectious diseases Influenza
Febrile disease Pneumonia
Accidents and injuries  

Note:

A population pyramid with a broad base and a tapering top are typical of developing countries.

questions.text: Leading cause of maternal deaths in India is:
questions.solution:
The leading cause of maternal deaths in India is hemorrhage.

Related Pearl: Maternal Mortality Ratio

Maternal death is defined as the death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the duration and site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes.

  • Maternal mortality ratio is the number of maternal deaths in a given period per 100,000 live births during the same period.
  • MMR = Number of maternal deaths in a period x 100,000 (or 1000)/Number of live births in the same period
  • Main global causes of maternal deaths are severe bleeding, indirect causes (anemia, malaria, heart diseases), infections, unsafe abortions, eclampsia, obstructed labor and other direct causes like ectopic pregnancy, anesthesia related complications, etc.
  • In India, the most common causes of maternal deaths are hemorrhage (leading cause), sepsis, obstructed labor, hypertensive disorders, etc.

questions.text: Jowar causes pellagra due to excess of
questions.solution:
Excess of leucine in jowar (sorghum) and maize interferes with conversion of tryptophan to niacin causing pellagra. (About 60 mg of tryptophan is required to produce 1mg of niacin).

People consuming jowar also have a higher risk of developing genu valgum and osteoporosis due to greater retention of ingested fluoride.
